INT. LENOX HILL HOSPITAL ROOM. MORNING

dialogues.speaker: INT. DANNY'S SUBARU OUTBACK. DAY
dialogues.text: Danny Meyerowitz, mid-40's, is backing up on the Bowery. He wears a soft brown leather jacket and shorts. Eliza, his 18 year old daughter, is flipping channels on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I'm really thinking about being vegetarian again. Eliza--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Do you realize, eating meat is worse than driving an SUV for a year.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Eliza, am I fitting? A car honks.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm parking asshole! (twisting the wheel) I can't believe that's true.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: It's true, Dad. Podcast. I'll send you the

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm fitting.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I'm telling you. It's a big thing we can do for the environment.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let's look it up. But not while I'm pulling THIS maneuver. He turns the wheel dramatically. followed by a thud. There's a scraping sound  2

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s too small a space. Shit!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He shifts back into drive and pulls out into traffic. horns. More

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to the car behind him) What?! Eliza fiddles with the radio, looking for a song.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Go back to the Mets game.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: It's a commercial.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I splurged and got the satellite. She lands on "Head to Toe" by Lisa Lisa and the Cult Jam. Ooh, nice.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Turn it up. Eliza turns up the song.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: "Head to toe --" (cutting himself off) I put this on a tape for you when you were like twelve.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (mildly interested) Cool. Danny looks over his shoulder, realizes something, and hi the wheel in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Shit, was that...was that a spot?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (looking back) Yeah, he's taking it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How did I miss that? Fucking shit.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Let's go around.  3

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We've been around. I'm going to try further East. (an idea) There should be an App for parking. Is there an App for parking?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: They're working on it. (re: the street they're on) This is all No Parking.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How did I do this wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: It's OK, Dad. Why don't we just garage it? Do you garage garage That's

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: know how much it is to it around here? If we it, you can't go to college. why.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (smiling) I'll pay half.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm not taking your money. (sighs) What's the matter with me? usually very good at this. It's OK-- I know. I'm

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm an extremely good parker. I have a real eye for it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Now, I'm over-thinking it. I'm getting gun-shy. Sweating, he wrestles with his jacket trying to take it off. He drives while doing this.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Dad, wait until weвЂ™re stopped.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m hot, itвЂ™s interfering with my mobility--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Let me help you then.  4 She leans over and helps him take it off.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (looking in the rear-view mirror) Are these the same people that were behind us?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (re: his jacket) Keep it right-side up, my walletвЂ™s in there. He turns the song down.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The song was distracting.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: It's too good!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (half smiling) It is too good. They stop at a light. Danny gazes outside.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (musing) There's so much construction in Manhattan. They're just endlessly building. I used to go dancing around here. At Danceteria. Me and your uncle Matthew. Now, it's all banks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: You guys went dancing together?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We went together, we didn't dance together. For a short time in the 80's we hung out. I had moves, I'm telling you. Is this a museum now? Everything's glass.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Do you like the photographer, Cindy Sherman? Marcus and me went to the Cindy Sherman show at MOMA last week. They start moving.  5

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (pointedly) Yes, I like Cindy Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (confused) What?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I told you about Cindy Sherman like two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't remember. I did!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And you had NO interest.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: When Marcus tells you, suddenly you listen. I'm telling you, I've got good recommendations. I mean, I have a few years on you. He hits the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Is this a spot? signs say? What do these

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Um, I'm trying to see. Another car honks behind them.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Quick, Eliza... Blaring honking.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I find parking signs confusing. What's today? Danny swerves back into traffic.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: This asshole is riding my tail.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I think it was a good space.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Can I back up?  6

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (looking over her shoulder) I don't think so. Horns!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Shit! He's on my tail. to go around. I've got

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: We should just garage it. Son.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A. Bitch! Of.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Stop yelling in the car! He can't hear you. Only I can hear you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (looking in the rearview) This is just Nobody Can Fucking Drive Day. (horns!)

dialogues.speaker: SHUT THE FUCK-EXT./INT. TOWNHOUSE, LOWER MANHATTAN. DAY
dialogues.text: The door opens with a light creak.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (softly) Yoo-hoo. Hello? Danny carries a duffel bag, holds a suitcase and walks wi a slight limp. Eliza follows behind him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to Eliza, concerned) The outer door was ajar. And the button on the foyer door was pressed and unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Something smells weird. A big poodle leaps up on Danny and Eliza. Oh wow!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Down Bruno! Bruno, down! Eliza screams.  7

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Whose dog is this? Brune!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Harold Meyerowitz, 70's, is bearded, wearing a green polo shirt with a knit tie and a knee-high work coat. He also has a red bruise on the side of his face.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (to the dog) Where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen and I bought him from a very elegant apricot poodle farm near the country house.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Hi Bruno! Oh, you're crazy, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (while hugging his Dad) Dad, the outer door was left open. (demonstrating) And someone pressed the button in on the foyer door-HAROLD Maureen is always doing something. (shouting) Maureen!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, you got to be careful. It's crazy to leave the doors open. This isn't the country.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (to the leaping dog) Brune! (to the air) Maureen! (to Danny and Eliza) This house isn't very big, but she never seems to be able to hear me. (again) Maureen! What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Did you leave the front door open?  8

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: For the Con Ed guy?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That was three days ago! He shakes his head, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we're late, we had to garage the car.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: And Dad had to sell me into child slavery to pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's basically right.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Did you try East?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY/ELIZA
dialogues.text: We did./Twice. The dog lunges at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Bruno! He does this elegant pirouette. Danny now reacts to the bruise on Harold's face.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad, what happened? into a fight? Did you get

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I was walking Bruno in the country when he lunged for a feral hare in the brush and I tumbled forward. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Did you see a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm fine. My joke is, you should see the other dog. He smiles slyly at Eliza.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Good one, Grampa.  9

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen won't even walk that path anymore. She was mauled by a buck. A buck?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: In the Berkshires?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A male deer. Really?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maybe it was a big dog or a small boy. In her indomitable way she survived with just a nasty raspberry on her knee, but her wallet was gone. He takes Eliza's hand and leads her further inside. They pass the living room where the TV is on the baseball game

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: The Mets just relinquished the lead.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Shit, it was tied when we were in the car.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Collins shouldnвЂ™t have left Syndergaard in. He was clearly tiring. Jean, 50's, rises from the couch, watching the game. Danny's older sister. She's

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I could tell Dad wanted to say Hi to you guys by himself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (startles) Hey. When'd you get here?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Your sister is here. Her hair is graying and she doesn't dye it. She wears a blazer with an abstract pin on the lapel and big hanging earrings and glasses. She dresses how she probably dresse twenty-five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Couple hours ago. showing up late. Thanks for

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sorry, we were--

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I made cookies but I stepped in dog shit. She hugs Eliza and Danny.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I like your jacket. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I like your pin.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Are you excited for college tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I really can't wait.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Dad keeps saying he wishes he hadnвЂ™t retired now so that you could take his class. If thatвЂ™s even allowed at Bard.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I couldnвЂ™t make sculpture, thatвЂ™s too intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She's very excited which I'm trying not to take personally. I'm bad with transitions.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You don't leave the house. are no transitions. (whispers to Danny) Maureen's plastered.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (yelling up the stairs) Maureen, every one is here! down! (to the group) She's making shark.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I don't think I've ever had shark. There Come

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen's a real gourmand.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (meeting Eliza's eyes) Well, you're in for a treat.  11

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (loud whisper to Danny) Maureen's been sober for six weeks. Oh, OK.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I tell her, I don't like you when you drink. She becomes a different person. (to Eliza) I made her a deal, I told her, if you stop drinking, we'll get a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE: A bowl of bouillabaisse. All the clam and mussel shells are still closed shut. A fork picks through the uncooked slab of shark.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This is very handsome shellfish, Maureen. Eliza makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: The Dad says you're going to study film at college. The family sits around a wooden table. Maureen, 50's, looks plastered. She wears an Indian patterned caftan and a big bulky necklace she probably got at a craft fair. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: That seems to be what everybody is doing these days. I think the Dad hoped youвЂ™d follow in his footsteps and take sculpture-HAROLD No, I think itвЂ™s good sheвЂ™s doing her own thing. Since Clarence had his stroke and I retired, the art department at Bard has really suffered.  12

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She's quite a good editor. Danny is trying to pry open a clam shell. Eliza moves the food around on her plate. Harold eats quickly and messily

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: So, now we have a sculptor and a filmmaker in the family.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (re: Danny) And a musician.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And an accountant which sounds uninteresting, but Matthew's in fact the only one in the family who's figured out how to make money. Sign of the times. He laughs at his own remark.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I would have thought we'd have had more artists in this family.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: What about Dad? Eliza looks over to Danny, who listens closely, perhaps waiting to be mentioned himself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (finally) I'm artistic.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Matthew showed interest in fine art and Danny had musical talent. But Matthew was also talented musically and a wonderful mimic. He looks at Jean and hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jean, you showed interest in photography.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: At Montessori, yeah. In my office at Xerox, I'm known as the resident auteur. I make funny movies for my co-worker's birthdays.  13

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: TheyвЂ™re really good. Danny finally breaks open his clam shell. He meets eyes with Eliza. She slowly shakes her head at him: Don't do it. He drops the shell back into the bowl, nodding, OK.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: We have no idea what Jean does at Xerox.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m a facilities manager for special--

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: When was the last job you had, Danny?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (helping out her Dad) Those piano lessons-DANNY Well...except for the piano lessons--

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: --and there was a gig at Beefsteak Charlies.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I haven't really worked in a...since Eliza was born...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Danny was a house-husband. But now with the separation, he's going to have to get a job. You can't take alimony, that's not right.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: What will you do for money?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, we just sold the apartment and we'll split that. (reassuringly placing his hand on Eliza's back) Karen...Karen is getting an apartment in Ditmas and I'm...I'll be staying here for a little, of course, while I figure it out. Thank you, again. He looks to his Dad for some acknowledgement. none. He gets  14

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: While you're staying here, would you please go through all the boxes upstairs and take whatever papers and posters you want from your childhood.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (to Eliza) Maureen is taking a fancy trip to Easter Island on Monday with a group.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: And when I'm back, we're going to start throwing things away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We donвЂ™t really have anything here.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We lived in Queens with our mother.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, itвЂ™s mostly Matthew's stuff, but OK.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Matthew's coming out from the coast in a few weeks. He corresponded with me about meeting for lunch. Danny looks up, surprised. Matt is?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Danny absentmindedly puts some shark in his mouth and the takes it right back out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He has some wealthy clients who are coming here on Sunday to look at the Dad's work.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Matt does?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Apparently they're both admirers of mine.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: We never hear from him and then suddenly...poof!  15

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That's not true, he and I correspond quite frequently.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: He texts with me. They all look at Eliza. Danny frowns.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You guys text? About what?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't know. Things. Life.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll try to see him when he's here.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He's only here for a day to see a client and he wants to see me during that time. Eliza, have more shark. Maureen, give my granddaughter more shark! Maureen heaps more shark on Eliza's plate.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You kids don't eat. Jean starts clearing. Maureen and Danny help her. Eliza remains with her grandfather, pretending to eat her shark We MOVE between the adjacent kitchen and the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It's amazing how much Matthew's clients make when you think about what a teacher or nurse earns-HAROLD I think I would have had greater success if I had been more fashionable.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Well, you were always out of step with the times.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That's true, I was a vanguard. L.J. Shapiro said that about me. Jean reenters from the kitchen bringing out coffee cups.  16

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You know L.J.'s having a retrospective at MOMA.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (didn't know) Is he? L.J. was always very political. He's not untalented, but he's a very skillful operator.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You didn't play the game.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You know L.J. and I showed together at Paula Cooper in the late 60's. And believe it or not, I was the headliner. Danny, still distracted by discussion of Matthew says to Jean:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do you think I should e-mail Matt about his visit? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't want to be presumptuous.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He's your brother, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Half. Maureen reenters.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Isn't that when the Whitney bought a piece of yours?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Yes. They were going to buy more work too, but Bernie, my dealer at the time didn't like the deal. I probably shouldn't have listened to him.  17

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (continuing to Jean) I don't know, he didn't respond the last time I reached out. Harold pries open another clam and eats it. disgusted face to herself. Eliza makes a

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: When I called and wrote the Whitney about it, they couldn't find it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's there.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: They can't find it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Jean, damnit, they have the work!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (chastised) OK, OK... Jean takes Eliza's full plate, rescuing her from eating anything more, and says in her ear: It's lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear family conversation from the other room. Danny turns the knob on the bathroom door. It opens and Maureen immediately comes out, wearing rose tinted glasses, but where you can see her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh...sorry. Maureen mumbles something. Danny enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny flushes. A strange rattling sound. He lifts up the back of the toilet. Inside, bouncing around the chain, ar several small, pint-size liquor bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Eliza sit at an upright piano. top keys, Eliza the bottom. Danny plays the  18

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: This is a Meyerowitz/Meyerowitz composition.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: We wrote it when I was nine. CUT TO: CLOSE on a book of Harold's work.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: The work looks stunning all together like this. Danny, you made this? Harold sits with Jean on a old corduroy couch. They eat cookies Jean made. Harold hands the book to Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (reading) Harold Meyerowitz: A Retrospective.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jean and I did it, yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You send in the pictures and they make it for you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (from the piano) Oh, Dad, Jean and I spoke with a woman at the museum at Bard-Danny looks at Jean who nods

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is that Hilma Federman?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hilma, yes. And there's some interest at Bard in doing a show-MAUREEN That's the least they can do for you after all those years you've given them. Maureen randomly clears a plate and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I think with Eliza going this fall and your history there as a teacher, we have a good shot--  19

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Danny, make sure Hilma sees the book. A retrospective at this point would be a real feather in my cap. And I think bring attention to the new work. Jean looks at Danny, who stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, the thing is Dad...it would be part of a group show.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Bard Faculty.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A group show? No. That's essentially an insult. I think Hilma's angry because I voted against her chairmanship. Tell Hilma, No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hilma hasn't offered it yet.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, when she does, tell her, No. Danny continues playing. Eliza and Danny finish the song.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: That sounded great. good, Eliza. You've gotten

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (putting her head on Danny's shoulder) I had a good teacher.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HAROLD'S HOUSE, BLEECKER STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Eliza waits with Danny outside the house.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Is shark bad or was that bad shark?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Dad, it was raw! The rice was hard, the shell fish was closed. Danny removes a piece of trash that's blown up on the wal He walks uneasily over to a trash can and chucks it.  20

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Dad, your limp is worse.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's always worse after I've been sitting. I need to stretch it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Please see someone about it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I have an appointment with an acupuncturist on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Someone real please. He looks at her. Tears run down her face.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, you're going to meet a lot of wonderful, interesting new people. Or I imagine you will as I didn't make it more than a month at college because I liked drugs so much.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I'm going to miss you and Mom. I know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY

dialogues.text: Oh, but we're so different, Dan.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: So different. We were raised like animals. We were feral! My worry is that we're too different. We're too close to our kids, don't you think? Parents shouldn't be best friends with their kids. I mean, I don't think my girls will ever move out! Danny laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I secretly hoped that about Eliza, but unfortunately she seems pretty healthy in that area. Loretta laughs. Danny smiles broadly, pleased she's so engaged. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to go. Danny startles. Dad-- Harold is right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Harold! (identifying herself) Loretta! Loretta hugs him and kisses him warmly on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh, Loretta. Hi. I didn't recognize you at first. (to Danny) I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: (re: the video) There's that little girl I keep seeing running down 79th Street! Loretta is swarmed by more well-wishers.  42

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (to Danny) I want to go.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (trying to keep it light) Just a few more minutes, roomie?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm leaving. Harold hurries toward the EXIT. Danny looks at Loretta, who is distracted by the bigger group-Danny gazes toward open one of the big glass doors. Danny hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Um, Loretta-She doesn't hear him. Loretta! He politely waits for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She smiles at him, still talking to the group.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (strangely pantomiming leaving) I have to go!

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You sure? You guys aren't staying for the dinner?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't think we were invited to-LORETTA (to her friends) Excuse me for a second. She touches Danny's arm, her face open and welcoming.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I better...

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (to Danny) OK. Well...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Great to see you. He's old.  43 So great.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: She kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I got your hair again. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: OK, bye Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Danny hesitates. She turns back to her group. he's blown it. He hurries after his father. Danny knows

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOMA/5TH AVENUE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Danny is hit by a blast of cold air. He looks around to see: His father is gone. Harold running toward 5th Avenue. Danny takes off after his father, but with his limp and t jump Harold has already gotten, he's quite a bit behind. Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Danny turns onto 5th Avenue. Harold is crossing the street. Danny hurries, dodging traffic. Horns. Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Finally Danny catches up to him, out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Dad! Did you hear me? Harold doesn't answer. Shit. Danny holds his hip.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: They slowly walk together in silence. rip: Then Harold lets it

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Ultimately L.J. is a popular but minor artist. There's a superficial bravura, but there's no unconscious, no discovery. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know you like the bears but it's a reshuffling of obnoxious cliches, like listening to music played slightly off-key.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I didn't get to see it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And the video work is embarrassing - I've never forgiven using Loretta in those pieces. You don't do that to a child. And it's a disturbing commentary on the culture that truly ordinary work, made mostly by his assistants, gets reverent reviews by critics who ought to know better. He's a talented, pretentious enigma. Silence as they continue to walk past the bright lights o 5th Avenue stores and office buildings.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It was nice to see Loretta.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (brightening) She was very happy to see me. gave me quite a kiss. She

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I did well, I was pretty funny, I think. I didn't get her number or anything. Maybe I can get L.J.'s e-mail from you-HAROLD I donвЂ™t feel comfortable giving it out. Maybe thereвЂ™s a work one. OK.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I met Sigourney Weaver who was very friendly. She said, "Hi, I'm Sigourney." I said, "Hi, I'm Harold." Danny waits, but there isn't more. He looks for a cab.  45

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Have you thought about getting a job? Danny shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You've essentially never worked in your life. Danny nods.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think you'd feel better about yourself. Danny nods.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Do you ever think about playing music again? Danny shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen will be back next Thursday and you should think about where you're going to live. I mean, you can stay a while longer, but-INT. HAROLD'S HOUSE. LIVING A clock reads: 9:40. Danny, still in his tux, walks by th piano and plays the opening chords of Van Halen's Jump. He eats a sandwich and makes up the living room couch wit a sheet and pillow. Harold appears in the doorway. He holds up black Vuarnet sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen wanted me to remind you to go through the boxes and things upstairs because we're going to start throwing things away. You might want these sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Those are Matthew's.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm letting him know too. CUT TO: Sitting on the made-up couch Danny dials his phon  46

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hell-- Hello? (laughter) Sorry...hello?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yo, how are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Sorry, Elvis is making me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Who...who's Elvis? What?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Joaquin's roommate. Oh, OK.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Who's Joaquin?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: He's a friend. What's up Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm at Harold's. We went to L.J. Shapiro's opening at MOMA.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Was it fun?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You having fun with Grampa?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I might go stay at Jean's in Rochester for a while. I'll be closer to you, but don't worry!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ha. OK. We're going to see this band and then there's a party. Can I call you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah...yeah. I'll be up early.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (hesitates) What's wrong? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I can hear it in your voice. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Tell me. Hold on, I'm going to step outside so we can talk.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, no, go to the concert. promise I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You promise?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: OK, I'm going to keep my phone on in case you want to call. OK?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: There's no need. Don't worry. OK.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Otherwise, let's talk in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Have fun.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But call if you need to. I won't. Bye Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWNHOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Danny lugs two big bags into the trunk of his Subaru. tucks them amongst boxes, a rug, a lamp. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front and back seats are also piled with bags and boxes. He starts the car. He fiddles with the satellite radio. Finds "Alligator Woman" by Cameo. Ooh.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nice.  48 He turns it up and sings along. pulling into traffic. He starts backing up and

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Don't fake me out, out/Oh, you make me shout/Alligator woman, youHe's greeted by a seren

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (erupting) Go fuck yourself! Go fuck yourself! GO FUCK YOURS---!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: Matthew had just arrived on the red-eye from LA. INT. RANDYвЂ™S APARTMENT The BLAST of JACKHAMMERS. CUT TO: An apartment wall comes crashing down. plaster and dust billows and clouds the room. The white As it settles we reveal Matthew Meyerowitz, mid-40's, crouched and holding his ears, his face still clenched in anticipation of the explosion. He wears a suit and tie. The man next to him, Randy, 30, is dressed in a white Vne

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Is that OK?! Is that OK?! Is that OK that that just happened?!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s OK! (to a workman) Right? The guy says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm scared, Matt.  49 Randy walks through the rooms, Matthew following him. Workmen swirl around them, under them, above them.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: These guys are six months behind. Matt hands him a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That's why I'm here. I put together a document that anticipates where you'll be at the end of the year vis a vis the overages.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (takes the sheet) Oh, for Christ. Really? already spent this much? Have we

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That's the first page...

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (turns it around) Suck a dick. Oh God. Another crashing sound. Really? Matt looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The change orders are adding up. We didn't budget for the salt water pool.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (smiling) But we're getting a salt water pool. In New York City, Matty. Every time I think of that pool, I do a Snoopy dance. He does a Snoopy dance.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Below you'll see I made a list of things I think you should consider cutting back on. Randy looks at the list.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (jumping up and down) No! The steam room makes me so happy.  50

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (consulting the sheet) You realize you have a steam room and a sauna? Randy nods innocently.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We have to make some decisions. (wiping plaster dust off his shoulder) It's too late to take out the sauna, but the Italian marble -the wine vault alone is a grand.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: You look tired. Matt's phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I canвЂ™t sleep on the red-eye.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Let's get you a coffee. Matt checks his phone. Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m glad youвЂ™re here, Matt.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not leaving until weвЂ™ve figured this out-Matt doesn't answer his phone and they s a room that's sealed off with plastic. More workmen. Hammering. Plaster dust drifts down on them.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (marveling) There are different people here every day. The coffee machine sits alone atop a folding table. Randy pours the beans into the grinder and presses the button.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (shouting over the grinding) How's your kid?  51

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Good. I'm in a fight with my wife right now, but... (re: the sheet) Randy, I don't want to sound alarmist, but you're not going to be able to sustain your lifestyle, if things continue like this. Randy frowns like a child.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And you're not going on tour any time soon -Randy hands Matt a coffee. smiles. Right?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Matt sips the coffee and It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: It's my own espresso bean. SEE, I'm doing everything I can to make a buck. The coffee will pay for the pool!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That might be too much pressure to put on the coffee-Matt's phone rings again. He looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: HereвЂ™s what weвЂ™re going to do. WeвЂ™re going to get you the pool. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: But not this year. WeвЂ™re going to rent out the bottom floor which is zoned commercial anyway and weвЂ™ll get a tenant for the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: But canвЂ™t I afford--

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The income from the rentals will cover the real estate taxes and youвЂ™ll live on the top two floors in the meantime. Everything else you can have.  52

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Let me just... (answering) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Coffee makes me so happy. A saw screams loudly in the other room. with his finger and goes to the window. Matt plugs one ear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold stands outside a restaurant. He wears a camel colored blazer with a black turtleneck and baggy slacks. denim flat cap on his head. He holds a poster roll and some envelopes and folders under his arm. He still has a slight bruise on the side of his face from his fall. They're jack-hammering in the street next to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: They won't seat me without you!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Where are you?!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm standing outside the place.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You're forty-five minutes early.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There are many available tables. The guy was a real jerk.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We have a reservation, did you say my name?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I said my name.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, let me finish up here and we'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How long are you going to be?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'll be there at one when we said we'd meet.  53

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, hurry up. Parking was easier than I anticipated.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'll see you soon! Matt hangs up. Randy is talking to a guy with an open notebook. He turns to Matt and says decisively.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: We wonвЂ™t do the pool now.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I think thatвЂ™s the right decision. Matt puts his hand on RandyвЂ™s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: (re: the phone) Everything OK? Totally.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Lunch with my father.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Say no more!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, now it's easy. When I was younger, I was so invested in his grievances, his anger at the world. They were mine too. Now, that I live three thousand miles away and have a good therapist, my own kid, a thriving business, I don't even get angry at him anymore. It's even just funny now... (suddenly having trouble clearing his throat) You know what's awesome about middle age, you now know more than your parents. You can guide the-(coughing a bit now) I'm sorry, I don't know why I'm suddenly, I think it's all this plaster dust and this coffee-RANDY (nods) You need something?  54 Like what?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Let's see--

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Randy fishes into his pants-pocket and retrieves two loos different sized pills. He picks some additional lint out of his palm.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: --one brings you up and the other brings you down, but I'm not totally certain which is which.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You have a guess?

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: I haven't worn these pants in a while. He hands them to Matt. Matt puts it in his breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: RANDY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Matt. I donвЂ™t have anyone in my life like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew hurries over to his Dad who has remained outside the restaurant. The street noise continues.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There's my son. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They hug awkwardly. Harold hands Matt the poster roll and envelopes and papers and the Vuarnet sunglasses. Matt frowns.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: These are yours. They were in the upstairs room. Maureen is throwing things out, I wanted you to have them.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (not thrilled to be carrying them) Thanks. The Vuarnets are Danny's.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He said they were yours.  55 No.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You can throw them out.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: They're quite fancy. (hesitates) Maybe Maureen will use them. He puts them in his jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We got a new dog, did I tell you? Maybe?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Bruno...my charge, we call him Bruno. Named for the idiot in Werner Herzog's Stroczek.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I've never seen it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Really? I own the cassette at home if you want to come over.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: So, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He lunged for a deranged hare taking me in the process. (beat, sly smile) You should see the other dog.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Are you all right? I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It wasn't his fault.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Shall we go in?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm not eating here.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Because they wouldn't seat you?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: The guy was very obnoxious.  56

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No, let's go somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I only have an hour and a half.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This is my protest. Harold starts walking away. Like McEnroe. Matt hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: OK, let me think... A man, 30's, Gabe, is trying to get Matt's attention from table inside the restaurant. Matthew indicates for him to follow them. Matthew and Harold walk. There seems to be construction everywhere they go. They pass wild-posting of ads for L.J Shapiro's retrospective at MOMA.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Not too far, because at three I have to put money in the meter. Gabe, sprinting, catches up to them.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This man is treading right on my heels.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, Dad, he's with me. This is Gabe, he works at my firm in New York. Gabe joins them on the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Mr. Meyerowitz. Gabe reaches out to shake Harold's hand, but Harold doesn take it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I thought Gabe could join us for part of lunch. His specialty is in estate planning-HAROLD I have an accountant.  57

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Barry Sukenick doesn't work on this scale, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I've had a chance to review some of the documents--

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And as we move toward selling the house, I think it might be a good time to get some affairs in order.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: If we sell the house, it will be my decision.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, Brian and James, who you met--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: They were a very charming, interracial homosexual couple. And smart about the work. They were familiar with Gilded Halfwing.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yes, James says they liked the work very much and they love the house. And they've made us an offer.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: For the work too?

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: For the work, the house, some of the furniture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the new restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to the hostess) Hi, three, please.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: If youвЂ™ll follow me-They follow her to the table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (pointedly to Matt) You know, your brother doesn't want to sell. Brother? They all sit.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Half-brother. We have a different mother. (to Dad) That's a real shame for him, then. Danny stands the most to benefit. He doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He and Karen have separated.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I took him in, but now he's with Jean in Rochester. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Apparently his mother moved to Florida, which I didnвЂ™t know. Did you know that? No.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s also still angry at me apparently. You know, your brother and sister have helped organize a show for me up at Bard.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: A retrospective?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A retrospective of the faculty, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Like a group show?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There are other artists, yes, but I've been promised a very prominent place in the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (politely) Sounds good. Congratulations. Gabe gets out some papers from his briefcase.  59

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: You purchased the property in 1973 for 60 thousand dollars. But since, you've borrowed against the house a couple of times, the net proceeds have diminished-HAROLD Danny thinks after this show, my work could appreciate considerably in value and that we should wait.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You just told me Danny doesn't want to sell at all. Dad, whatever happens at Bard, you can't afford the real estate taxesGABE You're paying two grand a month in utilities. Even things you wouldn't think, the housekeeper... Gabe--

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I'm just giving examples--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (sternly to Gabe) Mercedes has been with us for years. And although I deplore her politics, I'm not letting her go.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (re: Gabe) Am I paying for him?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, he's doing this as a favor to me. Gabe's specialty is not my specialty. I'm in personal wealth.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Something I wouldn't know about.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Gabe would only get paid when we sell.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm not giving Gabe anything. Absolutely not. And IвЂ™m not having this conversation with him. This is a private family matter. OK.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: I understand.  60

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Normally a conspiracy is mounted by people close to you. I don't even know this asshole. Harold stands up and walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) We'll get a check.

dialogues.speaker: GABE
dialogues.text: We didn't order anything.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (sighs, to Gabe) Sorry. Matt rises. He hands Gabe the poster roll and papers.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Can you take this to the office for me? To file?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, it's some middle school term papers and a Risky Business poster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Harold are stuffing bread into their mouths whil they consult their menus. They sit at a table for four at the end of a crowded banquette.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I wanted to punch Gabe in the nose.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The owner of this place is a client, that's why we could get a table so last minute. Matt continues, looking to impress his Dad even just a little.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That's why they gave us this bigger table... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I imagine they'll send us some complimentary stuff too... Harold struggles with a small aspirin container.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Is that Baby Aspirin?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Adult aspirin bothers my stomach. Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I've had some headaches. fine.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's Harold chews the two aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Have you gone to the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's not necessary. Matt lays two phones out in front of him. one iPhone. One Blackberry,

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You're so important you need two phones.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I saw L.J. has a show on at MOMA, I thought I'd check it out.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (proudly) I was at the opening. Sigourney Weaver. How is L.J.? Uh huh. I met

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We chatted. She said to me, "My name is Sigourney." I said, "My name is Harold."

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: L.J. says he's going to try to come to the show at Bard.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (politely) That's great.  62

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm sure L.J. would like to see you there.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (vaguely) If I'm in town...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to show the bronze sphere. It's an early piece I made when you used to sit on the floor and watch me work. You remember that?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You've told me this before, and I don't remember it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You would hand me tools and make suggestions as if you too were the artist.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It was originally untitled, but I'm going to call it "Matthew."

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) I'd like to see Eliza too. She sent me her movie which I thought was really good. Did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: At that time I thought you might be interested in sculpture. Or maybe an actor or a comic. You were a very talented mimic.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I do the voices of a lot of my coworkers which cracks peo the firm. (doing a voice) "I'm going to run downstairs for an esmoke." You don't know Ezra, but that's a pretty good imitation.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You were also very musical like Danny.  63

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: But Danny could really play.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He was chubby as a kid but surprisingly dexterous. No, that's true, Danny was quite gifted. I don't know why he didn't pursue it. I know he raised a child, but in this day and age, it's possible to do both.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: There are so many other things that factor in, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I suppose that's true, he had a difficult mother.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And poor Jean, I feel like she just opted out of...life. Has Jean ever had a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Or girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Apparently her office-movies show real ability.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I thought you'd do something artistic.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I work with artists. the temperament. I understand

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maybe Eliza will be my heir in that department. Although she seems more commercially minded. And potentially a lesbian.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Really? I didn't get that. (clears his throat) You know, I think I mentioned to you, I left the company I was with and me and a couple of other people started our own firm.  64

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen is talking to a friend who works at the Times about getting someone to come up and review the show. In recent years, I've been essentially ignored by the Times and I think this might put me back on the map.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It was scary, and a big change, but things have settled and we're doing really well. A lot of our old clients came with us. I think we're a great alternative to some of the bigger firms.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (showing Harold an image on his phone) This is our logo. Harold unfolds his collapsible drugstore glasses and puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Fifty-five dollars for a steak.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They're known for their meat here.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (reading the menu) And thirty-five dollars for a salmon. Do you get the salmon to blow you for that price? (Matt smiles politely) Do you want to split a salmon?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm going to get my own steak. didn't eat on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A whole portion is going to be too much food for me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Then eat what you can.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (pause) I'm paying. The waiter comes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm just going to have a starter.  65

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Have you guys dined with us before? Do you have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We have answers. Matt takes out the pill from his pocket. corner and tucks the rest away. He nibbles off a

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm going to have the salad-WAITER The little gem, OK.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (hesitates) --to start and then the steak.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: The six ounce or the twelve?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Twelve. And... (turning to Matt) Maybe a spinach for the table. The potatoes sound good. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Shall we get a wine?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Live it up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: And maybe this Brunello.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'll have the steak. And the market salad. And we don't have a ton of time so if you can bring everything at once... The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: How's my grandson who I never get to see? Here.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: 66 He shows a photo on his phone to Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He's quite handsome. so blonde. His hair is

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, that's his friend, Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh, he's the one with his hand in his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He was tucking in his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He looks like the child in Kubrick's The Shining.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That's the sweater, I think.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Handsome boy. Has the Meyerowitz eyes. Does he like the Knicks? I suppose he'll be a Laker fan since you're essentially an Angeleno at this point.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, but New York isnвЂ™t what it was. My artist clients are all moving out west now.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I've never forgiven Kobe for what he did.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's hard to have a relationship AND a child.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I imagine you've felt that too.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No, not really. I didn't find that difficult.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad, you've been married FOUR times. Three.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: The first was annulled.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I married her because of Tony, but... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't know, I think about what it would mean to leave, but...even contemplating it makes me feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Guilt is not a useful emotion. It blocks feeling. My advice is to go to work. Start a new project.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I work every day, Dad. office. I go to an

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't met his mother so I can't advise you in that department.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You could have met her if you'd come to our wedding.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You did it in LA.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: There are planes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I always felt you should have invited your brother and sister.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They're half. I don't talk to them or know them really...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You and your brother were quite close as kids. I remember you dressing like him.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He lived with us for one year until you kicked him out.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I didn't kick him out. He needed to go back with his mom and Jean. Your mom felt we didn't have enough space.  68

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, I didn't invite a lot of people, but everyone I invited, including Mom, came except for you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Well, if you break up what does it matter anyway? A fashionable European man and woman are eating at a smaller table next to Harold and Matt, in the same banquette. The European man, while in conversation, puts his glasses case on the Meyerowitz table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's so brazen. What?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This jerk placed his glasses on our table.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I don't think he realizes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: No, he knows exactly what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad, in terms of your estate, I don't want you to make mistakes that can be avoided.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Then they will be my mistakes. They're served their wine.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Before she dried out, Maureen drank half my wine cellar so I haven't had any good wine in a while. But she's been sober now for six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Is she still going to AA?  69

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s doing it her own way. Maureen is made uncomfortable by AA which I can understand. It's quite infantilizing giving away your control like that.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I think that's the idea.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I tell Maureen, I don't like you when you drink. You become a different person, I say. (exasperated) Do we look like we need two ketchups?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This son of a bitch just put his ketchup on our table too. The ketchup bottle is now next to the glasses case at the end of their table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Before you know it, he'll be sitting in my lap. The man balls up his napkin and puts it next to the ketch and glasses case on their table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I want to punch this guy in the nose.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's fine Dad, we have the bigger table. Just let it go. The man now places his wine glass on their table. Harold reaches over and takes a sip from the glass and puts it back. Matt looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad, what the fuck-The Man doesn't notice, however. He an finishing up and preparing to leave.  70

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Please don't do that again.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's my protest.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You better hope he doesn't have a cold. The European man grabs his jacket from the shared banquet bench as Harold and leaves with his date.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They're gone. Can you relax now? I'd like to relax now? So brazen.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) I think the Knicks might be interesting this year--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where's my jacket?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Right next to you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This isn't my jacket. (he looks around) That son of a bitch took my jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He has my jacket, Matthew. Outside the window, the European man and his date are talking. Their steaks are brought to the table.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He's still outside-back. I'll get it

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Shit, it's three o'clock. I have to put money in the meter. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (sternly) I'm not getting a ticket, Matthew.  71

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Fuck it, I'm going to grab the guy, you get the check and settle up?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I thought you were paying. I wouldn't have ordered that wine otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Where's our waiter? (loudly to the waiter) Excuse me! Excuse me! People look over at them. Dad--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Can we get a bill?! Matt is given the check and he instantly hands over his credit card.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (standing) You're not going to look at the bill? Make sure that it all adds up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We don't have time Dad, he's getting away.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We never got the spinach. Or any of the free stuff you suggested they might give us-EXT. STREET NEAR FANCY RESTAURANT Matthew is running after the couple who is about a half block ahead. Matt keeps stopping and waiting for his father to partially catch up, pointing in the direction he's going, and then running ahead again. Excuse me!

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: (immediately confrontational) What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Sorry. There was a mix-up back there. You seem to have taken my Dad's jacket. What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You have his jacket. We have yours. (looking over his shoulder at Harold in the distance) It's on its way. CUT TO: Harold is moving as quickly as possible. He stops to catch his breath. He watches his son up ahead talking heatedly with the European couple. He puts his hand into the jacket pocket and retrieves a small piece of white paper. He stares at it. CUT TO: The European man removes his right glove with his teeth and feels the material of his jacket with his bare hand.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: This is my jacket, man.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I think it isn't. he gets here. Just wait until

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: I know what jacket I took. He and the woman start to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (forcefully) I understand that, but you took the wrong one!

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: You're crazy, man. Matt is now furious.  73

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Listen, just wait a second, OK? Jesus, what does it cost you? Where you got to be?

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: So crazy, man. The couple walks briskly ahead. Matt. Harold is approaching

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Where's he going? Matt, turning it on now, catches up to the man and touche his shoulder. Hey!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Turn around! The European Man turns around violently, his fist clenche

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: You want to get hit, man.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What's your problem? Can't you see, you took my father's jacket. He has yours. What's the fucking problem?! Matt looks back at his father who is staring at the small piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad give him his jacket. What's that? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's a ticket stub to something called Fault In Our Stars.

dialogues.speaker: EUROPEAN MAN
dialogues.text: I don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Of course you do. It has kids dying of cancer. It was a big hit.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (suddenly) I've seen it.  74

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (incredulous) When did you see Fault In Our Stars?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: In the country at the Triplex. was quite affecting actually. Those kids are tremendously winning. It Matt and the European man stare at Harold.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Tell the man I want my jacket back.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to the man) Listen, give my father his jacket back and stop being such-A look of realization passes acr turns around to his Dad. He stops and

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad, how would this guy have your ticket stub to Fault In Our Stars in his jacket?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I guess that wouldn't make sense. Maybe this is my jacket. EXT. STREET NEAR FANCY RESTAURANT. HAROLD'S CAR. Harold approaches the car, smiling. No ticket.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: A stroke of luck. Matt trails behind, exhausted and still worked up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That guy was a real asshole.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He was. And we never really had our lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Fucking tourist. I should have said something more cutting. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I let him get away with being a prick. (annoyed at himself) That's going to eat at me.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don't want to come to the house? Maureen was going to make pigeon.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I have to go, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Where are you going? Matt hesitates, he doesn't want to have to say.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm going over to Mom's, actually.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Oh...maybe I'll go with you.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I don't know if that's-INT. MATT'S MOM'S APARTMENT We're in the midst of a conversation between Julia (early 70's and Matt's Mom), Harold and Matt. The place is warml furnished with books on shelves, old rugs, photos of family.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: --and that was the summer on Martha's Vineyard with L.J. and Maya and Paul and Lori.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We were staying at the Knapp house, the one with that peculiar blind dog.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: And Matthew, you were making up all of those card games, do you remember? And there was one in particular where I asked if it was based on luck and you said it was based on вЂњhope.вЂќ Harold gives Matthew a warm squeeze on the neck. smiles too.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You вЂњhopeвЂќ you get a good card. And thatвЂ™s what we would say all summer. вЂњItвЂ™s based on hope.вЂќ Matthew  76

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I was commissioned to make Gilded Halfwing that summer. L.J. was very jealous, I had already sold a piece to the Whitney.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Where do they keep that piece?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (defensive) It's not lost. They catalog these things.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I didn't say it was.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Harold, did you see? She points to a framed sketch on the wall. over to it. Harold goes

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You still have one of the sketchesYes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: --of Gilded Halfwing. looks good here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, Cody really admires it. says it gives him ideas. It He

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I thought Cody was a gym teacher.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: He taught Spanish at PS 182 and coached the soccer team. Matthew, Cody's sons are coming for dinner. I'm making a meatloaf. OK, good.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm starving.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I told Matthew, this seems like an elaborate ruse just to get his parents back together. Julia laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me that. Matt's phone is ringing. He checks it.  77

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This is Tony on Face Time, do you mind if I-JULIA Harold, do you want a coffee or tea or anything?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He has to go--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Tea would be nice. I can't have coffee after four. And if you have a Triscuit or something. I'm also starving. Matt steps away, somewhat hesitantly, as he doesn't like the idea of leaving his Dad alone with his Mom. He answer the phone holding it out to see his son on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hi, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm playing a game for a minute, it's called All The Animals Are Dead.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Can you move the phone up so I can see-- The other way... That's down.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Down then, honey. Matt watches his father and mother talking. Harold tea.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm in the middle of cooking for a big clan tonight.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is this my Buddenbrooks? What?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Harold removes a book from the shelf

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think this is my copy of Buddenbrooks. Julia serves  78 Harold looks back at the shelf for other books that may have been his. Matt, distracted by his parents, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Would you rather a beard made from paper or a beard made from a tree?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What's a beard from a tree?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: A beard made from a tree is like beard that is like a tree.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to Tony) Like the leaves on a tree? Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: But like a beard.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I guess a beard made from a tree?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Me too. (new one) Would you rather die from old age or kill yourself? Matt watches his Dad sloppily blow his nose into a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (almost to himself) Old age, I guess. Me too.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Did you give him regular milk?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (startles) Victoria, I didn't know you were there.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Of course I'm here, he doesn't know how to use the phone himself. Yes, I do!

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He has red all over his cheeks and chin, he said Daddy gave me regular milk.  79

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He likes it better--

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He can't have dairy.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We don't know that for a fact-TONY I'm going to press the button now.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: OK, I love you, baby.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Yes, we do know that--

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I'm pressing the-And they've hung up. Harold pages through the edition of Buddenbrooks. cooking at the stove in the background.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We were very thorough when we divided the books. That I remember.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (approaching his father) Me too. Put it back, Dad. He kind of half places it back.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I've been looking for this edition.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You've lived without it now for thirty years, I think you'll manage.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (walking back into the living room) You can take it, Harold, if you want. I've mostly stopped reading fiction.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad, I'll walk you to your car.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I can stay a bit longer. Julia embraces Harold. Julia is  80

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It was so nice to see you again. I think the last time was MattвЂ™s graduation. You know, I've always wanted to say, and I've thought about writing or calling, but I just never did it... I have huge regrets about how I was with Danny and Jean. I was a kid too, in many ways, and they were so angry at me. I took your lead, frankly, and we were starting over -- we had Matthew! -- and we didn't want to look back, which was understandable, but...I wish I'd been more nurturing of them, more generous, more mothering, really. I think they've suffered in part because of that and I feel terrible. Anyway, I just wanted to say that. EXT. MATTвЂ™S MOMвЂ™S APARTMENT. COBBLE HILL. NIGHT Matt walks briskly, a step or two ahead of his father.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's called flirting when you're young, I'm not sure what it's called when you're over seventy.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (pointing up ahead) You're just up here--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: She still has my drawing on her wall next to the gym teacher's doodle.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Cody's a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Your mother's more comfortable ultimately being with men who are half-smart, men she can dominate. I was much too formidable. After our separation, and before Cody, she was with a homosexual and before that a man who had no foot. They stop at the car.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Her fraudulent claims about not reading fiction I find offensive. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's masquerading as a populist so as not to threaten Cody, but it's a clever yet bogus subterfuge. It's a shame your mother, who knows better, has succumbed to this fashionable anti-art movement. This is why we have a Republican congress. Matt sees that Harold carries the copy of Buddenbrooks. frowns.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: She said I could have it. mine originally. He It was

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You have your keys?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: She was clearly very happy to see me. When it ended we weren't on speaking terms, but now you see that big hug she insisted on giving me. (pause) You know, Maureen always says your mother was the love of my life.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You taking the bridge or the tunnel?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I thought you were leaving tomorrow? That's why I drove all the way into Brooklyn.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm staying a few days. (coughs) I was around all this plaster dust earlier...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We have lots of room. Maureen is keen on seeing you as well. You know, she's your step-mother as much as Cody is your step-father.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I told Mom I'd stay here.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maybe you split half the time there and half with us?  82

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (snapping) I'm not splitting the time like I did at fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It was very important to me, after our separation, that I see you half the time. I wanted to make it up after Danny and Jean.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (with growing anger) Then make it up to them.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I made a real effort with you. Danny and Jean, I could have done better, but I don't see anything significant I could have done better with you.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Really? Nothing? You feel like that all was great?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Come on, Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Danny definitely got shit, and Jean didnвЂ™t EVEN get shit. But I got your focus and that fucked me up in a whole other way.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Matthew, we never see each other, let's not fight.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (furiously) I keep thinking I know how to handle you now, but then I see you and I get suckered into your shit all over again. Your career, your jacket! And when I try to actually help you like today, you WON'T LISTEN. Harold opens the car door and hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know how I could be such a bad father, look how successful you are. Right--

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I could never be the businessman you are.  83

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I've said to Maureen, I don't know who Matthew takes after. I certainly didn't know how to make money. Matt shouts across the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
