dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s right, I donвЂ™t take after you. None of us do. You had to be the only artist in the family. And it doesnвЂ™t matter that I make money because you don't respect what I do! Harold climbs in the car.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What do you need my respect for, the world respects you because you make money.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (throws up his hands) Ugh, I want to punch YOU in the nose! Matt runs around to the driver's side.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I know you think you can treat me this way because of your money.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter how much money I make, you make me feel like a big piece of shit because YOU DON'T

dialogues.speaker: CARE ABOUT IT
dialogues.text: Harold starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: But you also actually DO! You're privately obsessed with it. You know that I BEAT you! I BEAT YOU! The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What the fuck am I talking about? I'm so angry at myself for getting sucked into THIS! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (wailing, his head in his hands) I've wasted so much money on ther-TITLE: The Opening

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: In her twelve years as a neurosurgeon Dr. Malini Soni had seen such a dramatic shove. INT. NURSEвЂ™S STATION, PITTSFIELD HOSPITAL. DAY The sucking and periodic beeping sounds of a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's quite startling. CUT TO: CLOSE on a CAT SCAN

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: A collection of fluids on the left side of the head was shoving the brain clear to the right. A finger enters the frame, pointing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: His brain experienced so much pressure and irritation, that he was in an almost comatose state before we operated. Dr. Soni, an Indian woman in her 40's, and Pam, 30's, a nurse hover above a computer screen at a terminal.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: There was still some bleeding in the left frontal lobe, but no tissue was lost. The head trauma clogged up the spinal fluid absorption pathways which slows speech, causes lethargy, headaches. Dr. Soni straightens up and heads for the door. follows her into the -- Pam  85

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Honestly, this should have been taken care of immediately after the trauma.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Did you notice, his wife was heavily perfumed, but I think I smelled alcohol on her breath.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm worried about her as well. They both stop at a hospital room doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Jean sit in adjacent chairs. Danny, slumped, in his soft leather jacket and shorts stares into space. He has a brown grocery bag of clothes in his lap. Jean reads a book. They both look exhausted. Harold lies unconscious in bed, an oxygen mask on his fac and a drain protruding from a shaved portion of his head.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Oh, I didnвЂ™t realize anyone was here. The siblings startle and both stand immediately. Danny's bag slipping from his lap and hitting the floor, the clothes spilling out. Shit!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sorry. He starts collecting his underwear and socks. Sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not doing much...sleeping. Pam checks his blood pressure and oxygen readings. Good.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: You're family?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, we got here once we heard --

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Maureen only told us he was in the hospital this morning.  86 They look at one another, surprised they're both talking once.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Via text. We drove from Rochester.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We wanted to talk to a doctor. I'm Pam. Jean.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We haven't been able to get any information.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Soni.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Danny.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Soni, can you tell us what's going on with our Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: When your mother is here we can go over everything.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She's our step-mother.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We both have another mother.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: She would have been seven when she had me.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Well, when your step-mother comes back-JEAN We can't find her.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Her voice-mail is full.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why can't you tell us right now?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: This is awkward. What?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Um...I don't want to get involved in family dynamics, but she told me not to talk to anyone else.  87

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, that's not right, obviously. We're his kids.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You can talk to us.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: No, that's what I'm saying: since she's the next of kin, I legally cannot talk to you. I'm very sorry. They both stare back at her, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He has an opening on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (oddly) This is our first real hospital.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Talk to your step-mother...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PITTSFIELD BAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Maureen furtively exits the local bar, wearing her rose tinted glasses, and heads briskly down the main street.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Why did you tell the doctor not to talk to us? She spots Danny and Jean out of the corner of her eye and picks up the pace. Maureen!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Danny and Jean run to catch up. before. Danny, limping worse than

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (re: his limp) Are you moving that way on purpose?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What? No? It's always worse after I've been sitting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I thought you were mocking me.  88

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You don't walk that way.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I thought it was a bad imitation. Maureen!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We need to be able to talk to Doctor Soni.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Doctor Soni looks very much like a chum of mine from university who became an art looter, but that's of no use to you. No.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely none.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I'll get the information and you can ask me. E-mail might be best if you're going to be in Rochester. I'm here. I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Danny's here.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You have to tell her it's OK to speak to me or Danny or Matt, whoвЂ™s on his way.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: MattвЂ™s coming?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He texted me. I texted him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He texted you? You texted him? They reach Maureen's car.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Do you think I'm not going to tell you the truth? She opens the driver's seat door.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I can drive, Maureen.  89

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (getting into the car) Jean, you were wearing that same sweater that last time I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (baffled) Was I? Maureen starts the car, the siblings stand outside.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (emotional) Maureen, we've been sitting in that room with him and he's attached to those machines and there's a drain in his head and he's unconscious and we don't know where you are or what's going on? (snapping)

dialogues.speaker: TALK TO THE DOC-EXT. PITTSFIELD HOSPITAL PARKING LOT. SUN
dialogues.text: In the dawn light, a rental car pulls up. Matt climbs out of the back holding a leather overnight bag. He wears his suit, rumpled from the flight, with a T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt sits across from his father who sleeps. Oh, hi. Pam comes in.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Matt smiles tiredly. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: He's still sleeping? Pam, the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm Matt, the son.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Oh, I met your brother and sister.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Half brother and sister, yeah. he OK? Is I'm  90

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Dr. Soni spoke with your stepmother and then with your si -- half-siblings -- and it's all been cleared up and she can talk to you freely now. Oh...OK.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Your father was brought to us the night before last, but because he was taking baby aspirin, which thins the blood, Dr. Soni had to wait until the morning to operate.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: He had a chronic subdural hematoma, which in his case meant there had been steady bleeding in his head for some time.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How did he get this?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Something like this generally comes from a fall or if he hit his head-MATT He fell about four months ago. Bruno pulled him onto a path.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Honestly, I'm surprised he had such a delayed response. He must have a real tolerance for discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Will he be OK?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Well, because he waited so long, there was quite a bit of irritation in the frontal lobes and now that the pressure is off the brain, it causes severe agitation. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The frontal lobes are language. (pause) But itвЂ™s potentially a hundred percent recoverable. Harold opens his eyes and looks up at Matt.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (backing out the door) I'll leave you guys.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Thanks, Pam. Harold smiles brightly, almost innocently. back, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to his Dad) Do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Of course, it's Matthew. Matt, encouraged, holds up his phone.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Blackberry. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: This is...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What, Dad? This...

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's OK, we don't have to talk.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I can say it. (slowly but clearly) You're here. Is...what I wanted. Matt hesitates. Matt smiles  92

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How...how are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm happy...you're here.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I took a red-eye when I Yeah... heard.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: That makes me happy.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (wiping his face) Thank you, Dad. I'm sorry...we... I'm sorry this happened. Harold takes Matt's hand.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: When is my...? (he makes a face having difficulty with the word)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Your opening? It's on Monday.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is that today?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, today is Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Will...it happen?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It will happen, Dad. I don't know if you'll be able to go. Will you? Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You speak for me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I can say something, yes.  93

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It's yours... Harold smiles and closes his eyes. The first light from outside now arriving through the window.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: We made it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt approaches Pam.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I have a meeting in the City which I really need to go to. OK.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Um...sure.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That's OK, right?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I mean, he's OK, right? abandoning him?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I can't really answer that for-- I'm not

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I just have this client meeting.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He's OK, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (warmly) I think so. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You have my number. anything changes. Call me if

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt pumps gas and talks to Tony on Face Time. It's a chilly morning and he didn't put a coat on when he got ou of the car.  94

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm in Pittsfield. Massachusetts. It's in

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Is that like New York?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, it's a different state.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's sunny here. What's it there?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It looks like rain.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You can't fight the weather. can fight knights. Yeah. You

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: TONYвЂ™S VOICE And ninjas. You know who is good at playing ninjas? Jim.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Who's Jim? TONYвЂ™S VOICE He's a handyman.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I've never heard of Jim. TONYвЂ™S VOICE You used to live here but you don't anymore. If you did, you'd know Jim.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Do you see a lot of Jim? TONYвЂ™S VOICE He comes on weekends. Is this a weekend?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: In three days it's a weekend. TONYвЂ™S VOICE Three days! That's three weeks.  95

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, sweetheart, it's three days. Does...does Jim stay over? TONYвЂ™S VOICE No, Jim doesn't sleep. He stays up all night with Mommy eating dinner and leaves in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (addled) Hold on...I'm getting another call.

dialogues.speaker: TONY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Raise your hand if ninjas are your favorite thing. Matt raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Just a second, sweetheart. TONYвЂ™S VOICE IвЂ™m pressing the button.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, wait... Just hold on. Matt clicks over.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hello?...This is he...Shit...IвЂ™m coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open. Matt comes running out. with him down the hallway until he reaches-- We MOVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt enters. Danny and Jean are talking over each other.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Danny, stop, it doesn't help!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe if he hears it--

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (to Harold) Do you know who this is?  96

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (with difficulty) It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do you remember when you said: "Danny."

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You have to stop giving him the answers. Matt looks between his siblings and his Dad with confusio

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (pointing at Matt) Who is this? We SWING over to find Matt.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (vaguely) It's all right. Oh...no. ItвЂ™s Matt. here.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He just got

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Stop giving him the answers. A bald male nurse, 40's, enters. The nurse looks at Harol and says as if speaking to a child.

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: How are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (weakly) It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Where's Pam?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: Pam Engels or Pam Chin?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I don't know? I was JUST here and he knew what a Blackberry was and could say my name and everything. (to Danny and Jean) We talked about his show.  97

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (surprised) You were here? (and then) Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: Sometimes it can take a little while to come back from these surgeries.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (upset) No, he was already BACK!

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: (confused) I'm sorry, who are you? everybody? (laughs) I just got here.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We're his kids. Who is Where's Pam?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: I wasn't here, so I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I WAS! That's what I'm telling you. Where's Pam?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (hurt) Why didn't you call? you go?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I was heading back to the City for a meeting, but I turned around when Pam called-- Where did

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: Sometimes tiredness can cause this. And his blood pressure is quite high.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This isn't tiredness! Something is WRONG. Can't we find Pam?!

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: (offended) No, I'm the charge nurse.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to Matt) You were here. Why didn't you call us?  98

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (sharply to Danny) Because it never occurred to me!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Where's Dr. Soni?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: She's on her rounds.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Something is happening to my father! I want Pam!

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: (sharply) Ok, you're going to have to stop shouting.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: WeвЂ™re sorry, heвЂ™s just emotional.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: It's our Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not emotional, Danny, I want Pam.

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: Right now, we're waiting for a neurologist to read his EEG for brainwave activity.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: When will that happen?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's being read in India.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, because of... Why?

dialogues.speaker: MALE NURSE
dialogues.text: (angrily) In the meantime, I'm going to give him Lotensin for his high blood pressure. I'll be right back. He leaves. Matt turns to Danny and Jean.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He's giving him Lotensin. What did he get before for his blood pressure?  99

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Umm...the other nurse came through. She did something.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, she seemed to know-MATT Did you write it down?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can't remember... Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (furious) From now on everything gets written down. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (defensive) It's one thing. You can read what number it is now. He's alive. Jesus. These people do this for a living.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: These people change every five minutes. If we're not paying attention he might DIE. Do you understand THAT? Danny looks like heвЂ™s about to cry like a scolded child I do. Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'll write everything down.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYTHING.
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (angrily) Sorry! Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (yells) It's OK! Pause.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s nice to see you, Matt.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The lost speech could be because of frequent or partial seizures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Soni addresses the three siblings who listen attentively, scribbling in pads in their laps.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: An up and down is common but this is more of a down than expected. If it was his heart, we'd shock him out of it, but you can't shock the brain in these cases so we need to quiet the brain. The three siblings turn the pages in their books almost i unison but not quite.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: We're putting him in a barbiturate coma with a combination of Propofol and Pentobarbital or Phenobarbital. Probably Pento. I want to be aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Will he be OK?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Think of it like shutting down a computer and then restarting. Or if you're a luddite like me, like a grain of sand becoming a pearl. Jean laughs politely. strangely. Danny and Matt look at her

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Will he be OK?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Well, it's not what we'd hope at this stage. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because he'll be completely sedated we'll need to intubate. (warmly) I want you to know, we're doing our very best. We want to see your father walking out of here soon.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dr. Soni. She smiles and heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Now, I'm going to be on vacation for three weeks starting tomorrow-They all immediately st

dialogues.speaker: MATT/DANNY/JEAN
dialogues.text: What?!/What?!/Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: You'll be in very good care. Dr. Brotman will be taking over-Danny, standing, tries writin leg for support.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (writing) Dr. Brotman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soni walks briskly down the hall, the three siblings chasing her.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Do you have to go? you just push it? Can't

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We need you here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: (laughs) God, no, my husband will divorce me! WeвЂ™re going to China.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You're putting our Dad in a coma and then leaving us?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Matt, it's not like that. (then not sure) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's not, right Dr. Soni? not like that. It's

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: Well, technically, yes, it's that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You can't do that to us.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: First Pam, now you?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Can we get Pam back at least?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: I'm not in charge of the nurse assignments. (aside to a passing man) Hi, Doctor Liu.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It doesn't feel fair, Dr. Soni, that you can just live your live normally while our Dad is lying here.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SONI
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Maybe it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt and Danny end up next to each another, walking down the hall. Danny hums an indecipherable tune.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad said you started your own company?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, a couple of other guys and me decided to--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (trying to engage) So, how does that work? Do you just tell your boss, like--?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, I was one of the partners so I didn't technically have a boss-DANNY Right, no...so you got a better offer--  103

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, there was no offer, that's what was so scary, we were creating our own opportunity-DANNY Because you wanted something smallerMATT Bigger. Many of the firm's clients came with us-DANNY Which was surprising-They reach an elevator. Matt hits the button.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, we expected it. We can't legally ask the clients to come with us, but we trusted-DANNY But they don't have much choice-MATT It's totally their choice-DANNY No, I know, because you have their money-MATT Well, their money is with the firm. But their money is in investments or a bank-The elevator arrives. They get on.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I understand. My buddy, Ptolemy, he lives across the street, or lived across the street from where I lived-MATT Dad told me about your...Karen, I'm sorry. I've also--  104

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ptolemy is like you, he works in a... (fishing for it) Arbitrage.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's not what I do.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I wasn't saying-- But Ptolemy said the system is rigged from the inside-MATT That's not entirely true--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: But mostly--

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: So, this is an exciting time for me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How's your boy?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Good, Victoria and I are having some problems.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I never met her. separated. Karen and I

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I know, I just said I was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Did you? (pause) I'm sorry too.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (moving on) I liked Eliza's movie!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (surprised) She sent it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get off the elevator and head through the lobby towa the parking lot.  105

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Are you limping? Jean rises from a bench where she's been waiting for them Yes!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's always stiff after I've been sitting.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You should see the other dog. What? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I borrowed an old cane of MaureenвЂ™s dead ex-husband, but it's not really necessary. I keep it in the car. (pause) I'm telling ya.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAUREEN'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Danny and Jean help Matt move his stuff inside. carries a bulky printer/scanner. Matt

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's tax season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen serves the siblings a strange looking bird. Matt digs in and chews for a long time. Jean and Danny share a smile. EXT. MAUREENвЂ™S HOUSE. PATH AROUND THE HOUSE The three siblings walk Bruno.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: The Knicks need a point guard--  106

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MAUREEN'S HOUSE. BACK PORCH
dialogues.text: Matthew, Danny and Jean are playing cards.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Would you fuck Pam? MattвЂ™s considers this. I would.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Just kidding.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Jean, are you seeing anyone? Danny looks at Matt, surprised. No.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: INT. MAUREENвЂ™S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. LATER NIGHT Matt adds up figures on a calculator with lightening spee Danny, eats a huge sandwich. Jean flips through a photo album.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You were both such middle-aged men in the making.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOSPITAL GIFT SHOP. DAY
dialogues.text: The siblings stare at the various nick-knacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nighttime in the hospital room. Harold is comatose, intubated and hooked up to machines doing everything for him. He still has a drain in his head and feeding tube in his stomach. Danny is lying between two chairs, asleep. He dips slowly between the divide in chairs. A hand gently rustles his shoulder. He looks up. It's Jean. He nods, rises, gathers his things.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sleepily, but attentive) The night nurse today is named Rich. He's OK, but doesn't really know anything. Dad's blood pressure was 178 so they gave him Lopressor. It's down to 154 now. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wrote it down. Keep an eye on it. He hands her the notebook. I will.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Jean takes Danny's seat, props up her feet and takes out book. CUT TO: A nurse opens a curtain. Sunlight through the window. Jean is woken by Matt who relieves her.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: His blood pressure dropped so they put him on a Levophed drip, but thatвЂ™s hard on his kidneys, so make sure they keep him hydrated with the IV... Matt nods and takes her place at their Dad's side. CUT TO: Matt works on a stack of tax documents with his calculator. He hears laughter. He gazes into the hallway. Two nurses are looking at a menu. They chat casually.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It should taste really sweet too...it was a little gooey. Eww.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: It freaked me out.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Do I want meatballs? Matt watches. A machine starts beeping. Matt looks up suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --and overnight he contracted sepsis, which is a full body inflammation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, Matt, and Jean are confronted by a new doctor, Dr. Gonzalez. Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ
dialogues.text: Unfortunately the longer heвЂ™s here the more susceptible he is to infection.  108

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: What about his brain? an EEG? Do we have

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ
dialogues.text: This is a different unit, we're in the ICU, so I don't have those answers as of yet.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: So, now we're in the right unit to treat his sepsis, but the wrong unit to treat his head?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ
dialogues.text: (nods) They have a call in to a neurologist. People rarely come in on weekends.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Do people not generally get sick on weekends?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ
dialogues.text: We're working on getting you those answers. The doctor hands Matthew a pamphlet. shows it to Danny. He looks at it and

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ
dialogues.text: This is a helpful summary of the conversations you might want to have, things you might want to think about.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (reading) An end of life conversation?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR GONZALEZ
dialogues.text: It helps you prepare. In case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza meets the three siblings outside on the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siblings, Eliza and Maureen sit for an end of life conversation, taking notes. A group of doctors talk to them from across a large table.  109

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: These are things we suggest you say to your father before it's too late: "I love you." "I forgive you." "Forgive me." "Thank you." "Goodbye."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza unpacks a blue-tooth speaker and a phone from her backpack and sets it up to play music for her grandfather Danny places Harold's catalogue under the speaker as a base. She plays a loud Nick Cave song.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: He told me he liked this when I played it once. Eliza sobs at her grandfather's bedside. Danny, Matt and Jean regard this. They've been so caught in the hospital struggle they haven't had much time to be emotional.

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I want to say bye now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza and Matthew are at a table looking at Matthew's phone.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We just got on the phone!

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m going to press the button.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Hi Tony, you remember me? never actually met-MATT This is Eliza, your cousin? Wait... WeвЂ™ve

dialogues.speaker: TONY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m pressing the butt--

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Shit! Eliza laughs. Danny limps over with an unripe banana and yogurt on his tray.  110

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sitting) I'm oddly growing fond of this cafeteria, like IвЂ™d almost come here just anyway to eat. HowвЂ™s your boy?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: She fucking gets in his head. HeвЂ™s always hanging up on me now.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Call him back.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t want to call him back, it makes me feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s five years old. They hate phones. Eliza, when you were that age youвЂ™d never talk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: She makes it too difficult. I donвЂ™t know, sometimes I think maybe I sit this kid out and start another family and then he finds me when heвЂ™s twenty-one. Let him come to me. Danny gets up to grab napkins from another table.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: HeвЂ™s not a girl youвЂ™re trying to trick into dating you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Dad, your limp is worse.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's always stiff after I've been sitting.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I was looking on-line, it could be your hip.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's my back.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We should get you checked out.  111

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't have time to see a doctor now.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We're already AT a doctor. Eliza laughs. Danny sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I know what it is, OK?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's...I...I mean I basically KNOW.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Dad, you got to deal with it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Dan, I mean, look at Dad. He ignored his thing and-DANNY Just let me eat my fucking banana,

dialogues.speaker: OK
dialogues.text: Matt and Eliza share a quick smile.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And call your son! Matt hesitates and slowly gets up to make the call.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAUREEN'S DRIVEWAY. LATE DAY
dialogues.text: Maureen pulls into the gravel nodding hello to Matt who stretches before a run.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hi, Maureen. She drives past Matt. Matt continues to loosen up as we watch her car slowly veer onto the grass and roll down in a tree. Matt turns when he hears the soft impact. INT. MAUREENвЂ™S HOUSE. KITCHEN It's filled with dusty appliances, yogurt containers full tacks and coins, faded photos and outdated menus crookedl affixed with random refrigerator magnets. Matt finds a mu water pitcher with an old filter and fills it.  112

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: It's a shame the Dad is going to miss the opening tomorrow. He was really looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad asked me to say something. I was going to ask Danny and Jean too. He removes some mismatched bowls from a cabinet, looking for glasses. A Popov vodka bottle is stashed in the back. He turns around. Maureen quickly averts her eyes. Matt hesitates and takes the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He never would have expected you to have shown up. We were trying to figure it out, have you ever even been to this house before? No...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He pours her and him a glass of vodka. She hesitates, but takes it. She holds a frozen pack of peas to the bruise o her face.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: The Dad always hoped for a visit but I guess you always had a lot to do in the City when you came to town. And us not being A-list parents and all. Danny and Jean, of course, are here all the time, but thatвЂ™s less exciting for the Dad. Matt drinks his vodka.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I reached out to some of his old friends who are going to come visit.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (rising) I hope they understand they'll be looking at a sleeping man. Hello Andy Warhol!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I explained that. words. In so many  113

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I spoke to the neurologist, Dr. Diebert, who seems very knowledgeable, but has no upper lip to speak of, and if Harold survives the infection, they have no idea what person will be there when he wakes up. Maybe he'll be Brad Pitt. Or Neruda. Or Joe the Plumber. (with real feeling, but dramatically) I just want him to be Harold.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) Have you looked over the documents I sent you? Maureen rises and retrieves an envelope from a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Yes and given where we are with the Dad...and the Manhattan house is more than we need right now, IвЂ™ve taken your counsel, and I think selling the house and art to James and Brian is the right thing to do. I signed the places you marked for me. She hands the manila envelope to Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Then itвЂ™s done.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Some of those pieces are quite large, how will they be displayed?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (abashed) Well, you know, James's family owns a series of retirement communities around the country and they're going to donate the art to these facilities as a write-off.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Oh...OK. I canвЂ™t believe Danny is happy about that and Jean...well, who knows what Jean feels about anything.  114

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (trying to rationalize) Well, with DadвЂ™s illness...I thought IвЂ™d wait until after the show to tell them anything...I donвЂ™t know, thereвЂ™s been so much going on...

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Really they have no power anyway. I donвЂ™t know what happened to them as children -- Harold says he tried his best -- but theyвЂ™re really such disappointments.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (sadly) Nobody took care of them. Maureen nods.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I say that as a disappointment myself. I was neglected too during my childhood. ItвЂ™s funny, I was never interested in having kids. Maybe once. No, not even once. (drinks) YouвЂ™re very good at getting the most for your clients.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s what I do.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOSPITAL PARKING LOT. MORNING
dialogues.text: Danny, Matt, and Jean climb out of Danny's Subaru.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Eliza texted, she came early to be with Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She texted you?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: The curator is meeting us at Bard at one. So, let's get Eliza, say our good-byes to Dad and get on the road. A car door slams. They look: An old, frail man, 80's, is being lifted by his burly, muscular male nurse from the passenger seat.  115 Oh good.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Paul came.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Paul Epstein? I always liked Paul. Man, he's gotten older.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm glad Dad still has friends. (heading in the old man's direction) I'm going to say, Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Jean, you remember Paul and Lori? Jean?

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: (Jean's Story)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean wanders around the cement columns as she talks.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I wrote a short story about this once, but I never finished it and it wasn't very good. You remember that summer I visited Dad on Martha's Vineyard? Dad never invited me or Danny-Never.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: --that summer I was a camp counselor at French Woods in Vermont--

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: --to the summer places but-DANNY (O.S.) Was that the one with Alisa Lirtzman?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: No, that was Thoreau. I was only at this one for one summer-- And I had two days off, and I called him and he couldn't say, No. He must have gotten permission from your mother-- It wasn't as convenient as I had thought. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I had to take two buses and a ferry. When I arrived nobody met me. I hitchhiked to the other side of the island. When I got to the house it was already night and the adults were all going out for dinner. Dad and your Mom and L.J. and Maya and Paul and Lori. Julia said something about me having my bags in the way. They were happy to have a baby-sitter, so they left me with the kids. You were there, Matthew, and Loretta and some other kids I didn't know. We watched Three's Company on TV. The next day, Dad played tennis and worked in his studio. I went down to the beach with the kids. I got to swim in the ocean which was really special for me. I loved that. Later, I showered in the outdoor shower with my suit on. And I realized someone was watching me. It was Paul. He smiled at me, almost politely and then he lowered his tight bathing suit, took out his penis and started stroking it. Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Paul did?!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I watched him until he finished. Then he walked away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Did you tell anyone?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I told Dad that night and he asked if Paul had touched me and I said, No. He thought we should probably just leave it then, they were going back to the City soon anyway. But that if Paul did it again, he'd punch him in the nose. The next day when I was leaving, I looked around for Dad to say goodbye, but he was playing tennis. I thought about telling your Mom, Matthew, but I was afraid she'd get angry at me. I remember crying on my way to the ferry.  117 Matt and Danny look stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Jean, can I ask you a question? Why do you always show up for Dad? Why are you always HERE?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: (shrugs and says matterof-factly) Because IвЂ™m a decent person. Even though he never took care of us...itвЂ™s what you do. Besides, I like hanging out with you guys. Matt and Danny awkwardly try to hug her. away. She wriggles

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, aided heavily by his burly nurse, shuffles toward Harold's room.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Do we kick the shit out of him?

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: He's eighty. We'd kill him. Danny and Matt watch from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's true. Or hurt him very badly.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And neither of us can take that nurse.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's for sure. (starting toward the room) I'm going to spit on him.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (holding him back) No, I know what to do.  118

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew grabs a wooden branch, walks over, and smashes it over Paul's car. It breaks in two.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: But good too! (grabbing a rock) You got to try this. Oww! Danny comes forward, brandishing his metal cane and smash the roof with it. Danny looks at it, bent.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Shit, this is MaureenвЂ™s dead exhusbandвЂ™s cane. Matt chucks the rock, cracking the windshield. the car repeatedly. They're loving it. They smash

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I've never done anything like this!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Me neither!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run inside, high on adrenaline.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What's that blood? bleeding? Who's They stop and check themselves.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't see it. Your hand? Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And your face.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (wipes blood from his chin) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (thrusts his now bent aluminum cane in the air) Yeah!  119

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That felt great.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know why we don't do that more. Pam!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Pam is talking to another nurse in the hallway. She startles then smiles somewhat uneasily as they both rush toward her bursting with enthusiasm. They both hug her.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Last night his blood pressure was at 173 but they gave him Hydrolozene--

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And an extra dose of Lopressor--

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And got it down to 155. Oh good.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That sounds OK? He's also on Kepra and Morphine and...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's in our notes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Eliza's got the notes. Did you meet Eliza? She's my daughter. (lowering his voice) He has sepsis, Pam. Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And that's after the coma. Oh...

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Drug induced! Phenobarbital.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Pento actually-DANNY I thought it was Phenobarbital--  120

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What does it matter, we don't know what either of them are anyway?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (nodding) OK. I'll make sure to look in on him...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's so good to see you. come back to our unit. Please

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Are you bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers poke their heads in.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Umm, Eliza, we need to go.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (looking up) Um...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What? Paul is sobbing at Harold's bedside. The burly nurse gently rubbing his back. Matt and Danny hesitate. Danny indicates for Eliza to follow. She rises.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (crying) Bye Grandpa. I'll be back in two weekends. I love you. I forgive you. Forgive me-Come on!

dialogues.speaker: BURLY NURSE
dialogues.text: (to Paul) We should be getting on too. No!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Paul looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, could you stay here for at least ten or fifteen minutes more, you think? He stares at Danny and Matt strangely.  121

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is that Harold's brothers?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We're his sons. Matthew. Danny and

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You look just like him.

dialogues.speaker: BURLY NURSE
dialogues.text: Are you bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers run. Eliza behind them.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Let's go tell Jean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny, who holds his bloody hand, and Matt stand excitedl in front of Jean. They're both sweating.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Smashed it. What?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (points across the lot) Look!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (aside to Matt) He has dementia. What?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to Jean) We thought you'd be happy.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Why would I be happy about this? You smashed a sick old man's car. (re: Danny's hand) Let's get you a bandage.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (jumping up and down) I don't want a bandage. I want to let it bleed. Let's go to Bard!  122

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He has dementia?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (nods) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He has dementia.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, he didn't have dementia when he molested Jean.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: He didn't molest me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (losing steam) But let's not minimize it, Jean. What he did was shitty and damaging and I don't know...that same asshole is in there somewhere... Right? Beneath the dementia.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m glad you guys feel better. Unfortunately IвЂ™m still fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do you want to take a swing?

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I could smash every car in this parking lot and burn the hospital down and it wouldnвЂ™t un-fuck me up. (silence) You guys will never understand what itвЂ™s like to be me in this family. (opening her door) Let's go to Bard.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARD GALLERY. DAY
dialogues.text: A mix of faculty, students, artists and out-of-towners mingle amongst the work. Eliza gathers with her friends and Jean. And older woman, Hilma Federman, says to another teacher.  123

dialogues.speaker: HILMA
dialogues.text: He voted against my chairmanship, but I always liked him. From across the room an attractive woman, 30's, talking with a group, smiles at Matt. Matt, in his suit with a tie, smiles back. He stands in front of Harold's bronze sculpture which is prominently displayed.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This toast is really stressing me out. Danny appears and hands Matt a champagne. Danny wears his leather jacket over a shirt and tie and khakis with a hummus stain on the fly. Jean passes by on her way to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Jean, you sure you don't want to say anything? Fuck no.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Matt fishes into his pocket and produces the two pills.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I've had these for a while but I think theyвЂ™re still good. Want one?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What will it do to me?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It will either bring you up or down. Hopefully down, I guess?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (inspecting it) Someone took a bite already?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That was me. I had a crumb when I last saw Dad.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, OK. (pause) What did it do to you then?  124

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Made me annoyed at Dad? know. I don't Matt and Danny each take a pill and down it with champagn A blonde kid drapes his arm around Eliza's neck. Danny frowns.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What about Marcus?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They broke up.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How do you know that--

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: This woman keeps smiling at me. The attractive woman is smiling at Matt.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm getting a real energy from her. Suddenly, she excuses herself from her conversation and walks toward them.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She's walking over here. Matt runs his hand through his hair. I look OK?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you look handsome. Matt places his drink on HaroldвЂ™s sculpture. Danny quic removes it. She approaches Matt, her face blushing.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are you Harold Meyerowitz's son? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (pause) This is Danny, also Harold Meyerowitz's son.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m Nathalie Perry. I just wanted to say, your father was a huge influence on me. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was a great teacher, he found a way to make everything sound interesting.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (not what he expected) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I met my husband, Gary, in his class. Oh...

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: It was important to us to be here when we heard he was sick. He spoke about you a lot, he was very proud of you. (looks at Danny) I didn't realize he had two sons.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: L.J., (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that Matt and Danny! L.J. embraces Matt and Danny simultaneously. open and emotional while he talks. L.J. I was in Madrid when I heard. so damned heartbroken to hear about the old man. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He's very I'm

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks, L.J. L.J. How's he doing? Where is he? coming to visit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (releasing L.J.) He's kind of in a coma in Pittsfield right now. L.J. (tears running down his face) I don't give a shit. Let's go tonight. I'm  126

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (breaking the hug) And he has sepsis. L.J. It's the fucking hospital that will kill you. We got to get him out of there.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He'd love if you came even if he'll have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We'll take pictures. L.J. (squeezing them tighter) We'll take pictures.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (eagerly looks around) Where's Loretta? L.J. Her son got chicken-pox and she had to stay in town! She was very disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (disappointed) That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I never got chicken pox. L.J. You should call her, Dan. she'd like to see you. I know

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (resolute) I'm going to. L.J. You'd like her boyfriend too. He's a good man. A screenwriter.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BARD GALLERY. DAY
dialogues.text: Matt pursues Danny outside.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Don't beat yourself up.  127

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I should never have left that opening at MOMA. It was just...Dad... I felt obligated.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You thought you were doing the right thing...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You would've stayed.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I probably would've, yeah. But I would have felt bad about it. But it's a good lesson: Dad can take care of himself. You have to take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, he can't, Matt. That's why he's where he is now. (beating himself up) I should've been able to tell something was wrong. I just thought he was getting old...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Shit, I yelled at him. The guy was suffering and I screamed at him on the street. There's no catharsis in shouting at an old person who's dying.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do you think he's going to die?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad, I want you to meet someone, this is Robin. Eliza and Robin, the blonde boy, stand by the door with drinks. Robin smokes. Danny approaches, Matt behind him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: (trying to sound adult) You too. Eliza speaks very highly of you.  128

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh...OK. (to Eliza) You speak highly of me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: You know what he means. Eliza cracks open a beer.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Eliza, you've had two wines already, don't have a beer too.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Eliza, it's not good to mix wine and beer. You'll feel cruddy tomorrow. I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I've done it before, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Maybe she's right, maybe she has a constitution that can handle the grape and the grain.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Please, just...stay out of this.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Matt's right, I have the fortitude for it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, you're going to feel like crap. Eliza takes a swallow. Danny grabs the beer from her, and chucks it. Robin looks scared.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: What the fuck, man?! She storms back inside the gallery. Robin trailing behind.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What does it matter if she drinks wine and beer?  129

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Stop interfering with my parenting, Matt.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: She's eighteen. What "parenting" do you need to do here? She's just a person now.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: This is something I do and I'm quite good at it, OK? She and I have a very good relationship when you're not around. So, stop... ganging up on me. Matt reaches out and takes Danny's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (trying to diffuse) I'm sorry. You know, I've enjoyed hanging out recently.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Me too. You know, I've wanted to apologize for a long time. For what?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm pissed at myself because when Dad kicked me out of the house and I moved back with my mom, you really made an effort to hang out and I kind of blew you off. And I feel like I fucked that up. I think it's really my fault that we're not close. Danny hugs Matt strangely.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It was hard for me to be around Dad and your mom at that time too. They were so critical of me and I was just FAILING.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (trying to end it) We should go back in, give our toasts.  130

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (oddly) Are you disappointed in me?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, no. What? They both wander, moving, circling -- there's restless pe up energy that's slowly being released by both of them.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I know Dad is. But I felt like you maybe also were critical of me for quitting piano and-MATT No, no, no. You were my big brother, I looked up to you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I quit because it was my protest.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Like McEnroe.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And also...because it was like...it was like walking barefoot through broken glass to get to a milkshake. I loved the milkshake but, you know, my feet were...bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Can you? Cause my feeling about you is you can't. It's not your fault but like Dad, you make me feel really bad about myself. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I said it's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (leaning back toward the gallery building) Let's go in.  131

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (uh-oh) What?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: A few years ago, when Karen and I had you over to our house when you were in town and I never heard from you afterwards. Maybe you didn't like the food or Karen or I insulted you in some way. Karen maybe had too much grappa-MATT No! That was nice. I went back to LA, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Were you bored? Most people seem to find us interesting enough, we've had no complaints.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's nothing like that. It's just...life...it's not more than that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, even in life, you can make an effort. Write an e-mail from one of your phones. But, I guess you're fine making no effort with family. You say you have guilt, but...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (angry) I'm here now. I'm in fucking Rhinebeck. I was just in Pittsfield. I've been HERE.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (emotional) It shouldn't come to that! And if Dad survives, you'll go back to LA and I'm going to be taking care of him for a very long time.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: We'll all help out.  132

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No...we won't ALL. It'll be me. And Jean. And mainly me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'll come more often.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's what you said when you ate dinner with Karen and me. (walking away) You've made your priorities clear.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You know what: I'm tired of apologizing for doing well.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ptolemy asked me why you never talk Dad's work up to your wealthy clients. He says you could be really helpful, that it's all perception. You know, he's a good artist and there's no reason he isn't as well known as L.J.!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Maybe it's not my responsibility to help Dad. Maybe THAT.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, it's what you DO.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And ALSO maybe he's not so great. Maybe he's undiscovered for a reason. Maybe THAT! The truth is we DON'T KNOW, Danny. We were brainwashed.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why are you so angry at him anyway. He loves everything you do. Does he?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: He doesn't tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He tells ME. I should be angry at him. I should hate him for treating me and Jean like second class citizens.  133

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Then why don't you?! You SHOULD. He holds Danny's shoulder again, and says more tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Listen, you and Jean are going to get some money. We got a great deal on the house and all of the art and IвЂ™m giving my share to both of you. It doesnвЂ™t make up for everything but you guys really deserve this. Danny slips from Matt's grasp, angry.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad said this was a family discussion! Wait...did this...did this happen already? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s done.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He told me weвЂ™d decide together. And you do this when he canвЂ™t say anything... He told me, Matt. You werenвЂ™t there.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: If we didnвЂ™t do something, we'd be spending the next few years throwing his work in dumpsters. This way we get something for it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t care about money. That house, that work MEANS something to me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You should embrace this. I should be the one who cares. I grew up there. ThatвЂ™s MY house. I SHOULD care.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Then why donвЂ™t you?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Because...I donвЂ™t know... YouвЂ™re probably right, I should care. Maybe I do... Maybe I do... (hesitates) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But this makes sense, they're going to donate the art as a tax writeoff. James's family owns of retirement communities around the country-DANNY How could you do this to him? Who could even dream up such a plan?! Me!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It's what I do for a living. Danny shoves Matt. Matt shoves him back.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ptolemy said you guys make yourselves indispensable to vulnerable rich people.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell me more about my business? Danny, I really want YOU or DAD or FUCKING Ptolemy to tell ME about what I do every day for a living. Matt pushes Danny. Oww! Danny kicks him in the leg.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You kicked me in the shin. And now they're scuffling awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (blurting out) I WAS disappointed in you for quitting piano. Danny swings wildly at him.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What the fuck is wrong with you? I know it's hard, it's hard for all of us. GET IT TOGETHER!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (now, just shouting insults) And you're doing with Tony just what Dad did with me and Jean.  135 Matt slaps Danny hard across the face then slips on the grass and lands on his ass. Danny tackles him and they topple onto the lawn hitting each other awkwardly. People emerge from the gallery. them. College kids surround

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE KID
dialogues.text: Hey, he's beating up an old guy.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE KID
dialogues.text: No, they're both old.

dialogues.speaker: COLLEGE KID
dialogues.text: (shouting at the brothers) What's wrong with you two? They're rolling on the grass. Eliza and Jean try to stop them but can't get close with the flailing arms and legs. L.J. comes running out and lifts them both up and holds them apart in headlocks. L.J. Goddamn it, Meyerowitzes. Both are covered in dirt and grass and blood. clutches the side of his leg. My hip. Danny

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He collapses on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MATT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We want to thank Bard for making this show happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt, bloody, his suit torn, and still picking grass out his hair addresses the crowd. He consults note cards and talks smoothly and professionally despite his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: And thank many of you for making the trip. My Dad, and I'm sure every artist involved in this show, would be really pleased. Jean indicates for him to address the bleeding coming fro his nose. Matt wipes it on his arm.  136

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: My father was a teacher here for thirty-three years so this is particularly special for him. And this piece is special for me as it's called Matthew. My father tells a story of how this piece came to be. How I would sit on the hardwood floor of his studio, getting nails in my ass, and hand him tools and make suggestions and he would let me help or let me THINK I was helping and when it was done he said we had made it together. Even though I donвЂ™t remember this time, he does. But I remember that feeling. Of being very proud. Of wanting to be an artist like my dad. Of being included -- he was interested in me, he...loved me... (he wipes tears from his face) I'm sorry, I don't know why I'm... I've been angry at him for so much of my adult life. I guess I was trying to outrun him. But I didnвЂ™t -- IвЂ™m still that boy helping my Dad. And he loved me. Even if it wasnвЂ™t how I wanted him to love me, he loved me. And IвЂ™ve given away his lifeвЂ™s work--itвЂ™s gone... (to Danny and Jean) IвЂ™m sorry. And if Dad doesnвЂ™t make it, he and I arenвЂ™t OK. We never got to be OK... Danny is there beside him now, holding Matt in his arms. Matt continues to cry like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (to the audience, trying to sound intelligible, but just crying) Danny, do you want to say a few words...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, Matthew. He holds out the mike for Danny to take. anticipating a punch. Danny flinches,  137

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: No, I'm giving this to you...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, OK. Danny takes the mike. Eliza and Jean help Matt to a bench Now, Danny, also bloody, clothes torn, looks petrified. H hums an indecipherable tune. He leans on the back of a chair for support.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You'll have to bear with me as I'm not a good public speaker and also I've never done it. It's something I've gone to great pains to avoid. When I used to perform music in front of an audience it was just too excruciating. The reward was just not worth the self-hatred. Not to mention, unlike my brother, Matthew, I find this particular piece painful because it was during a time I wasn't really speaking to my Dad. He had left my mother and Jean and me, gotten remarried to Matt's mom whom we did not like. Again, unlike Matt, I was NOT included in the art-making process, it wasn't MINE too... This piece is NOT called Danny. In fact, there are NO Danny's. Or Jeans!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (nods) For me, it's a symbol of what I will NEVER be able to do. A club I will NEVER be admitted to. But Dad and I have gotten to spend more time together as adults and that's been good, I think we have gotten closer. We've certainly watched a lot of Mets games. Some of you know, my Dad is in a hospital in Pittsfield and we don't know how it's all going to go. Our doctor's in China and the only really good nurse got reassigned to a different floor. Maybe I need to believe my Dad was a genius because I don't want his life to be worthless. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If he's not a great artist, that means he was just a prick. I think he's good, though. I think he deserved more attention than he got. I think that's true. Matt? Matt, eyes bloodshot, face splotchy, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I wish he'd had more success because it would have made his life easier. Even if that kind of thing doesn't ultimately mean much. I don't know, L.J.? L.J. (shrugs) I don't know either. I'd tell you. If I did,

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Also, I'm really proud of my daughter, Eliza, who is a freshman here and a really talented filmmaker. Eliza's friends WHOOP. Eliza smiles, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thank you. (awkwardly) Peace. Danny drops the mike like a rapper.

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: Eliza liked kissing Robin the best, more than Marcus even

dialogues.speaker: EXT. METROPOLITAN MUSEUM. STAIRS. DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE: Eliza and Robin making out sloppily. Eliza, her hair very short now, and Robin smoke on the steps of the Met. Eliza and Robin are playing a game, trying to walk a thin sliver of curb while the other tries to push them over.  139

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza peeks around the corner. Robin behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, honey. She moves over to Danny's bedside and hugs him. Hi, Robin.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: Hey. Robin hugs him too, surprising Danny. Jean stands and hug Eliza. A card game on a tray-table is mid-play.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I love your hair. Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Robin cut it.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I wish I had the guts to do it. Do it! now.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Robin will do it You think?

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: I've got scissors in my bag. Eliza grabs a chair. Jean sits down.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: How's the hip?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm bionic now. That's a reference for Jean only.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I know what bionic is. I don't.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: It's a show. (smiles, to her dad) You taught me well.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: We don't like the nurse today-DANNY She's not nice.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Kathy is more conservative with the pain medication.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And we can't find the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: You know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: But spirits are high.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Eliza's NEW MOVIE. She's nude hitch-hiking. She's having sex with a creature in a field, and she has mustache. Jean appears holding hands with a rabbit. Jean!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: That's you with the rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shh, you're going to miss it. Danny watches the computer which rests on his lap in bed. Jean (her hair short now!), Eliza and Robin look over his shoulder. Jean!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You were so good.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: She's got real chops!

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I was well edited.  141

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's wonderful, honey. I don't know that I've seen a sex scene shot quite like that before.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: I used deliberately very harsh, direct light. I wanted to appear very unattractive.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Well, that's difficult.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: (smiles) You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Wonderful mise-en-scene.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: For my Jeopardy parody I did at my office, we just had to use the overhead fluorescents.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yours had wonderful mise-en-scene as well, Jean. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And this is the best yet, Eliza.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad. I've made eight more since then.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: I'm in five of them!

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MAUREEN'S HOUSE, PITTSFIELD. DAY
dialogues.text: Matt gets out of his rental car carrying bags of Chinese food. Bruno barks. Maureen greets him. She wears round clear glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (to the dog) Bruno-(to Matt) Did you change your scent?  142

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I don't have a scent--

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Maybe a new shampoo?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (mussing his hair) I don't think-MAUREEN The Dad is being very stubborn. can't get him to do any of his exercises. Bruno!

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: How's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: The earliest appointment we can get with the neurologist is next month... It's a lot for me to do by myself here. She enters the house through the kitchen. Matt follows.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Fortunately we have a little more money from the sale. James sent photos of the sculptures at one of the retirement homes in Arizona. They look quite stunning. (pause) I have to say I was very surprised that you tried to stop the deal after you went through all that trouble setting it up...

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I just thought...I changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Well, it was my decision as IвЂ™m the next of kin. ItвЂ™s too late now. She retrieves the black Vuarnet sunglasses from a pile of odds and ends and hands them to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I found these in the Dad's things. I think they're yours.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: They're Danny's.  143 He puts them in his jacket pocket. Maureen enters the dining room. There are papers strewn across the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I just have to finish these insurance forms which seem to be written in a foreign language-MATT Maureen, why didn't you ask me, someone at my company will do that. She looks up, tears falling from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: (emotionally) I don't like to ask for help.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (softly) Let me do it, OK? He steps forward about to place his hand on her shoulder, but she quickly recovers and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: But it's a big day, it's the Dad's first meal off of the feeding tube. INT. MAUREENвЂ™S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM Matt follows into the living room. Harold is watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: He's watching TCM. Matt hesitates. His Dad looks older and wears a knit cap. There's a weariness and frailty he carries now. Hey, Dad. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: What are you watching?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know. Matt sits down next to him and they watch.  144

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: In these 30's movies the men wore tuxedos all the time. Things have gotten much more casual.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Maybe they dressed up because they lived shorter lives back then. They wanted to celebrate life.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: INT. MAUREENвЂ™S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM Matt and Maureen sit beside Harold who lies in a bed made from the pull-out couch. Bruno sleeps on the floor. They eat take-out Chinese food. Harold eats quickly, his bites large.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: We spent three hours today at Goodwill. The Dad had a funny joke.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What was that? Oh.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: I'll set you up again: We spent three hours today at Goodwill.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Which pretty much destroyed mine. Ha.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: That's good, Dad. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You should see the other dog. Harold has no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: That's true, the Dad got very impatient. And as we were handing over the boxes, I saw that I had accidentally included my good wok. And I hesitated. But I thought, I haven't made Chinese food in ten years. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I won't make Chinese food again...but you have your idea of yourself and you want to hold onto that. Harold erupts with a guttural cough.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Dad, are you OK? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (spitting food back on his plate)

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: We just got you out of the hospital, we don't want you to go back.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It was very unpleasant in the hospital. Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You know, I was there for a couple of months. I know.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen has been my savior.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Harold, you're getting brown sauce all over the sheets. Harold wipes at the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: You're just rubbing it in. Maureen sighs and gathers the plates.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Matt can you help the Dad get ready for his nap?  146

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Sure. IвЂ™m going to try to come visit more. ItвЂ™s hard, because Tony starts kindergarten this year, and I want to be around for that, but... IвЂ™ll try to be here more.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: L.J. is coming for lunch in a couple of weeks, you should come for that. Maureen heads into the other room.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: He left me a very effusive message about my show. And someone wrote a rave on my Google. It was quite inspired of you to set that up.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Jean and Danny organized it, Dad.
