dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Is that right? But you made the sale.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Yeah, that was me. But, I bought a piece back from Brian and James at a significant mark up, I might add. ItвЂ™s the piece from the show, вЂњMatthewвЂќ because... вЂќMatthewвЂќ and we did it together. (formal but from the heart) Thank you for letting me be part of your process. It had a big effect on me, Dad. Your confidence was contagious. I think itвЂ™s why IвЂ™m able to do what I do now.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I remember I made вЂњMatthewвЂќ in 1966, the year the Whitney bought my piece. CLOSE on Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: It couldn't have been 1966.  147

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: It was, I didn't work in bronze after that.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I wasn't born yet.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (the impact of this lost on him) Oh...that's right, isn't it, then it couldn't have been you watching me, could it. Maybe it was your brother. Matthew hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I guess I wanted it to be you.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You should have called it вЂњDanny.вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™re right. I should have. I'm going to sleep now. Can you close that shade? OK.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Matt rises and pulls the shade.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s OK if you want to sit here longer while I fall asleep. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Matt comes around to his father's bedside. His dad remove his hat and balls himself up in his sleeping position lik an infant.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I love you Dad. Love you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Matt tucks the covers up to his neck, leans down and kiss his Dad on the forehead. He sees, hidden in his fatherвЂ™ hair, the scar from the surgery.  148

dialogues.speaker: INT. LENOX HILL HOSPITAL ROOM. MORNING
dialogues.text: Danny opens his eyes. The room is empty except for Matthe who sits by his bed. He wears his trifocals and looks ove various financial documents.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey, my broth-a.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: My broth-a.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks for paying for this. private room is...it's not necessary. The

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I can get work done this way.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How is Dad?

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know, still Dad. But I was sitting there and I just kept having this thought. This is my Dad. This is my...Dad. This is the same guy as all the other times. And that thought which has made me so angry also made me love him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I said goodbye to him so many times in my head, it's strange, in a way, I wasn't prepared for him to survive.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, now weвЂ™ll know what to do the next time. The three of us had a real rhythm going...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I just don't want to have to speak publicly again. You know, sometimes I wish Dad had done one horrible, unforgivable thing. Something specific I could be angry about. But it isn't one thing. It's tiny things every day. It's drip, drip, drip...  149

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I couldn't stop the house and the art from being sold. In the end, Maureen was determined.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I'm over it. I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Matt rises and removes the Vuarnet sunglasses from his coat.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I think these are your Vuarnets.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (takes them) I thought they were yours.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (hesitates) Maybe they were mine.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I think you're right, they're mine.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (reaching for them) I'm remembering now owning them.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (pulling them away) They look like a pair I probably had. Danny puts them on. Matt regards him.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You can have them anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Can you help me walk? The nurse is supposed to be here to do it, but I get antsy. Matt helps Danny climb out of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I loved Eliza's new movie.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's good, right.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You've done a great job with her.  150

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks. You know, I'm glad she likes you so much... Danny holds Matt's arm as he slowly walks.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Hey, when you get out, do you want to come to LA?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh...hmm...I love Los Angeles. I haven't been there, but I love it.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: You could stay with me, see what you think. You know, the weather is nice, I could get you a ticket and in a couple of weeks-DANNY I don't know, I think I should stay and help Maureen with Dad. I have sympathy for her but I donвЂ™t trust her.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: Well, if you change your mind... They continue into the hospital hallway.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: I was going to stay here longer, but I think I should leave tonight and get back to Tony because...I want to be a Dad like you.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, go be with your boy. (pause) Thanks for...you know, taking care of me.

dialogues.speaker: MATT
dialogues.text: (shrugs, smiles) It's what you do.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAUREEN'S KITCHEN/LIVING ROOM, PITTSFIELD. DAY
dialogues.text: Harold sits, partially slumped, at the breakfast table.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen went into town for groceries a few hours ago... Danny places a plate of blueberry pancakes in front of hi He walks with a cane.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The famous blueberry pancakes. Danny does the flourish.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I don't know what she could be doing...

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How's her drinking?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I've made her a deal, I said, we'd put in a pool if she stopped drinking.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (unsure) Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You know, since the Bard show, Matthew has personally invested in a a piece of mine.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You should have seen Matt, Dad, when you were sick. He was there the whole time, he really whipped us into shape. Harold gets up and walks into the living room. male nurse's aide who is cleaning up.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think you and Jean should look into getting me a solo show. That would really put me back on the map. They pass a  152

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You know, we were all there the whole time. Harold sits on the couch and presses the remote.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) Every time I turn on TCM, it's Meet Me in Saint Louis. What's on the premium channels?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It was rough there for a minute, we thought we might lose you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: There's something called Sex Tape on Starz. Do you know anything about that?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (giving up) Not really.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Shall we give it a try? He places down the remote and settles in.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: Maureen is leaving for Cuba on Monday. I thought you could stay with me while she's away.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You know, Matt invited me to LA.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I'm still recovering. could use the help. I really

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to LA?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: You're still recovering too. And, you know, we've got the premium channels now. We get the Knicks.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I know. I lived here while you were in the hospital. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (helps with a pillow) You'll have a nurse with you-HAROLD You know, I really need you to stay with me. I'm asking you to do this, please. You know I donвЂ™t like asking for things. I need you, Danny. OK.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: I think there are still some of Jean's cookies in the kitchen if you take a look-Danny goes into the kitchen. The male nur doing dishes. Danny nods at him.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll take you to lunch one day this week at Babalouies which is the best pizza in the Berkshires. Maybe the best pizza period.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: OK, thanks. He picks up the plate of cookies-HAROLD (O.S.) Pick a day. Except for next Saturday, L.J. is coming up for lunch, so you'll need to find something to do, but you can go to a movie or, I think there's bowling. Danny throws the plate of cookies onto the ground, startling everybody including himself.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (to the nurse's aide) Sorry. Danny!

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Danny stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Sorry, Dad, I didn't think that would be so loud.  154

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD
dialogues.text: See if you can rescue some of the cookies from the porcelain.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm leaving now, Dad. I'm going to drive back to the city-(again to the aide) You'll be here, right? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'll clean this up, don't worry. (back to his Dad) And then I'm going to LA to see Matthew. (and to himself) "I love you." "I forgive you." "Forgive me." "Thank you." "Goodbye."

dialogues.speaker: DIP FADE
dialogues.text: The sound of HORNS and CONSTRUCTION.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOWN CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Danny grabs a handful of complimentary gum from a tray an puts it in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: The flight leaves at 4:30, you think we'll be OK?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, traffic looks fine. And you're business class, so check-in is quicker.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I've never flown business class. I've never done business. My brother had miles. He removes the Vuarnet sunglasses from his pocket and put them on. He gazes out the window. Loretta, in a sweater and jeans, walks briskly down the street, holding herself against the cold.  155

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Can you stop the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta continues walking. Loretta!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Loretta's mouth widens into a big smile. Danny emerges from the town car wearing his big Vuarnet sunglasses and holding a cane.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Danny! (they hug) I'm consulting for a client around the corner and I just ran out for a tea without my coat! What are you doing in Stuy Town?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Just going for a ride with my chauffeur. No, I'm kidding... Um, I'm on my way out to the coast. The coast?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Los Angeles, really?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, thus the town car. Matthew got it for me. I usually take the A train. (removing the glasses and indicating the car) This is not representative of where I am in my life. Loretta laughs and touches his arm affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm going to stay with Matthew for a while...

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Oh, that sounds nice, get out of this weather.  156

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah...I don't know. weather. I like

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I know, me too, I don't know why I said that. (pause) What's this cane?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh...it's this affectation, I'm trying...NO, no...new hip.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Oh wow, Dan. Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah...better. I did my best to ignore it, but the hip won out.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: (realizing) Oh my God, how's your Dad?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He's OK. He's out of the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: That's great. My Dad was worried.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah...he's better...health-wise, otherwise...the same.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Sometimes they're just the same, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's still waiting for his life to begin.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Oh no, but he's done so well, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (honestly) I don't know, has he?  157

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: He has. He taught for all those years at Bard -- I used to love hearing him talk about art, he made good work, his kids are great... It's a shame he can't feel that way. CLOSE on Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (realizes) Yeah. (suddenly) There's so much I believed without knowing I believed it. They both smile silently.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I guess it doesnвЂ™t matter if your parents are alive or dead, weвЂ™re still trying to change the ending, arenвЂ™t we? But you look different, Dan. I canвЂ™t put my finger on it. And itвЂ™s not just the limo.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: L.J. mentioned you were seeing a screenwriter-LORETTA Oh yeah...that didn't take. You know, after my divorce, I don't know what I'm doing. I'm single now.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (abruptly) I won't be leaving New York for good. I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: That's what everyone says when they go to LA and then it's twenty years later.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: See you in twenty years. Ha.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: No, I have to come back for Eliza's freshman film festival anyway in a month.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Can I come?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's at Bard.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'd love to come.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's, uh, not un-pornographic, I'm warning you.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm in the art-world, I've seen it all.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She's really talented, I think. You know, I think she's got something...

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: I'm sure she does. talented family. It's a

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm telling ya.

dialogues.speaker: LORETTA
dialogues.text: Well, that's something to look forward to, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: I/E. WHITNEY MUSEUM. DAY
dialogues.text: Eliza and Robin shove one another playfully and make thei way inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An art handler, holding a slip of paper, leads Eliza and Robin down a long, cramped, crowded hall of painting and sculpture packed away and stored on various levels. We pass by many labels, with many famous names. They arrive at a crate. kneels down to see: A faded label on the side. CLOSE: Harold Meyerowitz: Abstraction #7, 1966 Eliza  159

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: This is him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: That's so cool. Eliza nods. FADE TO BLACK.
